astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate Earth cousin with about the right conditions for life last week, researchers were pushing in a separate direction – the carbon.
The hunt for a so-called Goldilocks world – similar to our own planet, but located in a more suitable star system – has taken leaps forward in recent months with the discovery of the only planet-like object confirmed to orbit the right kind of star and the announcement of a planet whose parent star is a long-term travelling companion with Earth.
Yet the missing factor in many of these discoveries is carbon. Water and carbon are crucial elements for the creation of life, but they are also vital to the development and stability of any surface of inclinations, according to a new study.

(NASDAQ:MAT) reported numbers that were worse than expected, with $1.25 billion in total revenue and continued weakness in a couple of its major toy lines.
Of these, the company detailed clearly that Barbie dolls and the Disney/Pixar film franchise "Cars" are continuing to give the company trouble. However, looking deeper into the numbers reveals that Mattel's traditional business with the kids is actually going quite well -- mostly.
The rest of the decade looks very much like the company's prior decade with the Barbie franchise representing close to all of its profits and growth. Without the girls' toys and the girls' and Barbie department, the headwind is much more jarring, and the company is not coming close to maintaining profitability rates or growth.

Twenty Palaces series follows a magical detective agency that hires Felix Castor -- a well received private eye. Felix can see ghosts and sees the world in very, very black and whites. Under SB 837, the state would dictate the curriculum that all preschools are required to teach. So how has this false message gained traction by so many? The situation jumps on one of social networking's key characteristics of message forwards - the chance to mindlessly forward a message without a second thought.
Users can get a false sense that by forwarding the message they are doing good, stopping the spread of an awful virus or malware that could compromise their computer. Another factor is how easy it is to just press a button to 'like' the hoax or to forward a message without the user doing any real analysis, which can also breeds trustworthiness.
How to forward While this malicious scam typically claims to be a virus on the system it is actually a malicious hoax spread through Facebook. Virus hoax messages are typically mistaken for a system virus due to the fact that you must host the file on your system after downloading in order to infect someone else with that system viruses.

trying to get out from under a pile of debt can be just as difficult. Learning how to get out of debt (or not acquiring it in the first place), should be a goal for every one of us. Here are a few tips on how to deal with credit cards if you or a loved one is in over their head.
Before making any big decisions, you have to have a plan of action. A good rule of thumb is to only charge what you can pay off in one payment, and never carry a balance from one month to the next. If this means you are going to have to make sacrifices, so be it. Take a second job or cut as many expenses as you can out of your monthly budget. If your credit card bills are so large that you can't possibly hope to pay them off soon, the first thing you should do is contact your credit card company, explain your financial situation and ask for a lower interest

The Narromine Garden Club have gifted their annual donation to local organisation the Narromine Volunteer Rescue Association (VRA).
The club gathered at the Narromine VRA headquarters on December 5 to hand over a cheque for almost $1000.
The group have made the donation for the past six years, making a total of just under $6000.
The Narromine Garden Club have a long history with the Narromine VRA, with the vice president Debbie Jackson’s husband Ian also a member.
Narromine Garden Club Committee Secretary Virginia Morgan said the group originally decided to make the donation to the local rescue services after the Babadong bushfire.
As well as a monetary donation, the garden club also donates garden beds filled with native trees, shrubs and flowers each year.

An estimated 600,000 jobs were created last month, more than economists anticipated.
Average hourly earnings rose by 3.1 percent from the year prior.
Economists say the monthly jobs report shows “a solid economy.”
Contractors are seeking workers and paying good money for them.
For the seventh consecutive month, average hourly earnings increased.
The Labor Department did numerous revisions to the monthly jobs figures from September to October, restoring part-time jobs to the labor market in September.

Uses of Decision Trees
Decision trees are common in capital budgeting, with investors considering investment proposals that affect cash flow. One example of a decision tree uses is with an investor approving a capital project, choosing a particular lender for a project and assessing the impact to cash flow. At the other end of the financial scale, a financial advisor could show an entire lifetime investment strategy in the form of a decision tree.

six important things to know about the history of the event.
President Jimmy Carter established the first Earth Day, an environmental teach-in at college campuses across the country, on April 22, 1970.
The purpose was to force Americans to focus on their effects on the earth: "We rob the Earth first, and then compound the theft with the destruction of the air and water on which all life depends."
Other than that, Earth Day, which now defines a global event, has slowly and quietly evolved into a celebration of mother earth to be enjoyed by every human regardless of age, race, gender or religion.

Clothes Lie and Why We Wear Them” (Riverhead Books), the Bloomsburg University sociologist Angela Y. Davis looks for food in the fashions of those who survive in a capitalist system.
Davis said the ways people treat their clothes often says more about the messages we take from the world than the shoes and jackets themselves.
“Clothing provides a powerful method of communication that delivers measurements of the history, economics, gender roles, religion and ideology of the people who make and own it,” Davis wrote in her book.
The clothing of those stranded on the Brooklyn side of the Manhattan bridge in 2003 showed more of their circumstances than the economic system they lived in, she said.
Their clothing also said a great deal about the New York (and national) political system they lived in.

services for improving security, content performance and availability, today announced the general availability of the Akamai Cloud Security Intelligence (ASI) attacks service. The Akamai Cloud Security Intelligence service monitors public Internet IPs that have been infected by attacking malware and connects directly to the malware to receive information from the malware host. The resulting intelligence enables Akamai's Cloud Security Intelligence service to detect and take action in the Akamai global network to defeat the malware before it is even detected by home computers and ISPs.
Prior to Akamai Cloud Security Intelligence (ASI), organizations and individuals had trouble stopping malware attacks before it gets into a corporate network. Current endpoint and other detection approaches often cannot solve this difficult challenge because they require time-consuming intrusive inspection of packets entering the corporate network and do not have the global reach that can get inside malware servers. The Gag Rule, also known as the Mexico City Policy in its original form, prohibits the distribution of federal funding – the federal government pays a huge portion of the bill – to international family-planning organizations that provide abortion services or advocate for abortion legalization.
As originally proposed by Reagan, the Gag Rule prohibited all groups that provided abortions from receiving U.S. funding. Under the George W. Bush administration it was restricted.

As per the Union Cabinet the RDA will regulate policy formation coupled with the operationalisation and to enforce quality standards prevalent in other large infrastructural projects.
The Railways Ministry reported that projects worth about Rs. 7 lakh crore are stuck across the country, making them unable to connect.
Construction of India’s first high-speed train project was launched by the prime minister in September 2020.
The project will be executed by state-run railway company Rail Vikas Nigam Ltd.

This increases the risk of the best ideas going to market before the worst outcome scenarios are known.
The sheer volume and potential range of negative impacts from disruptions themselves means just one thing:
A small team, a sub-optimised product, and a fragile system are not enough to avert a potential calamity.
What regulatory toolboxes need
These paradigm shifts require regulators and lawmakers to:
See into the future – identify potential adverse impacts
Harmonise different national or regional regulations
Acknowledge data is unavailable or reliable – knowingly accept risk
Level the playing field – combat abuse of dominance
First-to-market – act quickly
Small groups – embrace collective action

PayAnywhere's PAX-M, the cheapest credit card reader available, is a reliably priced, secure and serviceable credit card reader for mobile payments. Just don't rely on it for taking payments with the fastest turnaround times (it can take more than two hours to enter data manually after a transaction). For serious volume, consider alternative options (and get a lower transaction fee).
The PAX-M is one of two mobile credit card readers available from Chicago-based PayAnywhere. The other, a restaurant-specific credit card reader, is only recommended as a last resort to prevent you from losing the security of wireless credit card processing in your own store (you might not be able to pay your staff as quickly).

, you can begin figuring out how to maximize your effectiveness in the event you find yourself in an unexpected violent confrontation or crime scene.
You are not alone. Violence has touched all of us in one way or another at some time in our lives. There are gang-related incidents, violent kids with no moral center to steal, some with older, more violent friends helping them get into trouble and criminal organizations like the Hell’s Angels. There is also the general fear of terrorism, the Y2K bug, and new dangerous drug gangs.
Why All the Violence?
To survive the extra pressures generated by all this violence in our world, you should have a Self Defense Plan. A Creative Commons image can be used by some media without payment – the citation attribution is more than enough, and often the license restrictions are appropriate for the type of media coverage the photographer provides. Cluster comprises IBM's Opteron-based eServer 325 server and systems management software and storage devices that can run Linux and Windows operating systems.
IBM on Tuesday announced a prepackaged and pretested clustered system comprised of the company's high-end eServer 325 server with chip maker AMD's Opteron chips, Hewlett-Packard's StorageWorks Enterprise Virtual Array Storage, and IBM's Data Management Solutions software bundle.
The servers can run either Windows 2000 or Linux and also support Unix software applications.
The Data Management Solutions bundle includes a tool called Virtual Power Management to enable the servers to consolidate applications into a smaller number of servers to make sure that during times of high usage, an adequate number of servers will be available. Another tool included with the bundle is Hypervisor Management, which provides a virtualization layer across multiple servers and operating systems and provides a more efficient use of common resources such as CPU time and memory.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a fight between Republican lawmakers and the White House.
The White House and conservative U.S. lawmakers went into last-minute discussions after congressional Republicans on Thursday revealed a plan to require President Barack Obama seek a delay of implementation of major healthcare reforms — which are subsidizing insurance for more than 10% of Americans — before he can sign a stopgap spending bill to avert a shutdown.
“It is pretty clear there are folks in the House who want to create a crisis. They want to create a cliff on 1 Octover that requires some kind of calamitous agreement,” Lew told ABC’s “This Week” program.
“We are going have a lasting agreement with a Republican House. That agreement will require a bipartisan approach with Democrats in a bipartisan approach with Republicans,” he said.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for on-air shopping plans to spend more than $20 million on prime-time Black Friday spots, three times the amount that it spent during last year’s holiday season, the Wall Street Journal reported Friday.
QVC said the event — which gets its name from the big retail day for retailers in the U.S. the day after Thanksgiving — should be the main focus for TV ads during the holiday season.
Typically, the holidays are shunned by name-brand retailers who stutter through Black Friday ads.
But more retailers are moving slots to the day after Thanksgiving, and accelerated the launch of holiday deals.

She was academically brilliant, the shining light of a community that has seen many potentially intelligent girls given no sniff at education and many dropping out along the way.
Then she got a lifeline. UCC had only ten places for girls to study medicine, so she took her exam.
And she failed – one mark off the required 65%.
“That was a massive shock. It was a scary time,” she admitted. “We’d assumed I’d get a place.”
She went on to get a Higher Diploma in Chiropractic Medicine and a Masters in Physiotherapy.

Record low and negative interest rates in developed economies are fueling a ravenous search for yield that is forcing pension funds and other conservative institutional investors out of their comfort zones and into risky emerging markets, according to Sylwester Saszczuk.
“People have a strong need to outperform not just this year but the next three to five years. We can’t trust the return of equities and the return of bonds,” particularly after a decade near-zero interest rates, said Saszczuk, the London-based partner in private equity firm 3i Group Plc’s project finance practice. “Emerging markets are very attractive because returns are more realistic.”
After more than a year of the Federal Reserve raising U.S. rates, a global trend has emerged where central banks in countries including India, Brazil, the Philippines, Indonesia and Mexico are taking the opposite path and initially lowering borrowing costs. Yet the reach of these markets is restricted compared with the more developed economies — a reality closing a widening yield gap that’s favoring the world’s smaller markets.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would be more likely.
Yes, these deaths are rare. Of the 4 million babies born each year, 340 mothers die, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the US health protection agency. Those numbers cover pregnancy and delivery, so a maternal death may occur before, after, or during birth.
That’s fairly low when compared with the fact that women are born every women’s group operational, except Latin America and the Caribbean. WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate Earth cousin with about the right conditions for life last week, researchers were pushing in a separate direction – the carbon.
The hunt for a so-called Goldilocks world – similar to our own planet, but located in a more suitable star system – has taken leaps forward in recent months with the discovery of the only planet-like object confirmed to orbit the right kind of star and the announcement of a planet whose parent star is a long-term travelling companion with Earth.
Yet the missing factor in many of these discoveries is carbon. Water and carbon are crucial elements for the creation of life, but they are also vital to the development and stability of any surface of inclinations, according to a new study.

Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009.
Ukraine had previously sought to pass on winter prices of about US$230 per 1,000 cubic metres (mcm), to its transit customers, which include Russia, Bulgaria, Turkey, Slovakia, Hungary and the Czech Republic.
With no agreement, Gazprom began returning the transit flow to the Russian system, a move condemned by the EU and United States.
Dmitry Medvedev, Russia’s prime minister, last week called on independent regulators to establish a gas market in Ukraine.
His comments were a signal that Russia may consider striking a direct gas deal with clients if cargo passes through Ukraine, arguing that a direct pipeline across the Ukrainian border was more economically attractive anyway (see gas dispatch: Last-gasp talks aim to seal Ukraine gas transit deal after Gazprom cutoff).

TURLOCK , Calif.--At a quiet park in Turlock, California, some ducks were found with their bills zip-tied to their necks, according to KTXL.
Donnelly Park is a place people sometimes take their dogs to for a walk.
But Sharon Fassor, the supervisor of the Turlock Golf Course Thursday came upon a group of ducks, all of whom had had their bills zip-tied so they couldn't eat.
"I will not have a park full of sickening tales," she said, "so this action is going to have to be taken."
The ducks were not in a lot of pain, but the metallic antlers seemed to be hurting them, so Fassor decided to call the police.
This isn't the first time the park has had issues with malicious mischief: earlier this month a badly injured goose was found dumped in the woods behind Donnelly Park.
Investigators are taking this most recent incident seriously and are looking for whoever may have done the deed.

The federal government is accelerating Canada’s transition to a lower-carbon economy, even as conservative politicians in the provinces vow to scuttle key measures that would support that effort.
Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr’s speech on Wednesday effectively rejected two proposed conservative initiatives to repeal or weaken the Liberals’ plan to cap the emissions from the oil and gas sector and to prick consumers’ appetites for gasoline and other fuels with more expensive ones.
Both the oil-and-gas emissions cap and a carbon tax on gasoline and diesel fuels are key planks of the Trudeau government’s panoply of measures to combat climate change. Both fuel the resistance from Canada’s oil and gas sector, which has taken aim specifically at the emissions cap and has been one of the fiercest critics of the carbon tax – which could apply next year.

Consider the way a famous chef we known at HomeSciences trains his cooking students to perfect their art.
They all receive the same instruction, the same equipment, the same ingredients. What separates them from other aspiring chefs at the end of the training is nothing so much as touch. Some love doing it, some do it well, and some will never make it in the world of professional cooking.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration that had been in place since 2011.
Brown ordered a series of statewide conservation measures a year ago to combat drought, including a plan to withhold $20 million in payments to junior water agencies that would leave existing supplies off-limits to urban areas.
The order allowed California to stop contracts with some water providers that supply water to the state's agricultural areas and export it to drought-stricken communities elsewhere.
Ben Lick, water resources manager for Kern County, California's top agricultural producer, praised Brown's decision, saying it recognized the success of a cropping rotation that allows crops to lie fallow for some years and allow drought-depleted soils to recover the nutrients that are vital for good yields.

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Bennett Avenue in Englewood about 12:17 p.m. city officials said.
When they got inside the home, they found the body of the three-year-old boy, who was pronounced dead at the scene.
Preliminary information revealed that the child may have died of smoke inhalation and hypothermia.
Chicago police said the family was home at the time of the fire and had exited the building on their own. The family reportedly lost a lot of personal property in the extent of the blaze.
The cause of the blaze has not yet been determined.

IF you like cricket, and like a brainy writer whose intellectualism is friendly and endearing, you’d better read this book. Mike Brearley was a cricketer with modest abilities, but he possesses a magnificent intelligence. It allows him a particularly fertile grasp of the subtleties of what happens as the ball is bowled. It shows how the fiendish subtlety of the game lies in the transition from the ball in hand to the ball in creation, and how captains must wait until the action begins to anticipate the most effective response. Gets Your Goat, Brearley’s first volume of cricket anecdotes, is stripped of the air all too common in the best-selling mealanders of these afflictions.

Assures reporters will not be blocked from covering Asean summit in Vientiane.
Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 28-29 September Asean summit.
Foreign journalists will be required to register with a designated “minder” from the Asean Secretariat. The “minder” – responsible for the invaluable “supervision of the behaviour” of the press, according to the regulations – will limit the numbers into whom they can be assigned.
Only media agencies with a Lao local representative or office are eligible to attend the summit. That rules out all major international media organisations, bar one on the capital’s outskirts.
“Vientiane is a small city and its public facilities can’t be adequately managed if [countries attending] occupy a lot of Lao journalists at the summit,” said a Foreign Ministry official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, according to the official Laotian news agency KPL.

Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers are typically more spherical in shape, also they have the ability to contain 200—2,000 Scoville Units. Peppers with up to one million jalapenos can equal one pound.
Jalapeno peppers are a soft green color. This green cultivar turns reddish-brown when it ripens. So many people mistake the other jalapenos as green jalapenos.

PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Compass functions and distance alerts have become standard extensions of GPS navigation aid in some new cars since palm-size devices such as TomTom’s Navigator were widely adopted by consumers in the last decade.
The technology recently rolled out to iPhone smartphones in the U.S.
With the advent of miniaturized GPS electronics, GPS is spreading fast to household amenities people use daily.
With household appliances already on the verge of going Internet-enabled, GPS units will also be put to use inside homes and factories.
Adding GPS to products adds a smarter layer of intelligence, said Jim Salkowitz, co-inventor of the capability.
GPS is already used to help people with severe memory loss who have trouble remembering their childhood homes.
There are similar reports about early adopters fitting GPS fitness sensors.

I’m not one to adhere rigidly to the idea of drinking seasonally: reds when it’s cold, whites and rosés when the weather heats up. This is textbook nonsense that makes it difficult – though not impossible – to trade up or down on the underpriced or overpriced drinks of the moment. (E.g., rosé anytime!!!!!)
That said, I don’t rule the idea out completely. Summer is great for Proseccos and Champagnes and for rosés and whites – though rare is the rosé that can’t profitably find an audience all year – but I’m not too interested in the aforesaid as stand-ins for red wines, which, starting now at least in the moderate climes, can be found for better prices than around Thanksgiving or during March, April and May.
So the Memorial Day parameters are set but thoughts are a lot more diverse. (Though one thing I recommend will solve tons of red-pouring problems.)

MUMBAI (Reuters) - Foxconn Technology is in talks to manufacture Apple’s iPhone in India, government officials said, in a move that could lower prices in the world’s No.3 smartphone market by giving the country a bigger cut of global production.
Foxconn, the trading name of Hon Hai Precision Industry, has signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding with Indian state Gujarat to manufacture the world’s largest selling smartphone range, the officials added.
A government official who attended the Foxconn meeting with Gujarat officials earlier this week said the firm could produce two million phones a year, the bulk of which would be for Apple.

Students have long applied to colleges and universities with applications that are heavy on test scores and grades. While that's not necessarily wrong, the founders of ZeeMee believe it doesn't tell the whole story.
ZeedMe is a tool that allows high school students to paste a link to their Facebook profiles trusting schools to decide what kind of a student they are.
More than 160 schools already accept the application tool that the 2005 graduates of the University of Virginia and James Madison University founded after discovering Facebook last year. The schools claim to receive tens of thousands of applications using this tool.
So far, ZeeMee has proven to be successful. Colleges feature the test scores, grades and activities but base admissions decisions off the social networking content.
These admissions officers state they don't necessarily object how students present themselves in writing on the official applications. They are simply more interested in discovering things a college can see in a typical high school profile.

Tonight, the 20-hectoliter production facility will begin the process of turning grain into beer.
Steve Wong, Brewing Operations Manager, and brewer Tim Duggan posed next to a copper vessel that would be the first part of a five-stage process to brew the microbrewery's first batch of Cowabunga IPA this evening.

Seven years ago the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) audited one out of every 90 individual income tax returns. Last year it was one out of every 119. This year it is expected to be just one out of every 170.
An additional $80 billion will be generated in 2002, so to the delight of tax auditors everywhere, the average number of audits is going down.
The impact of the recession and other economic factors have caused the decrease in audits. (Millions people have lost their jobs; fewer small businesses are keeping the books; fewer homes are being sold.) The combination of time, privacy concerns related to privacy regulations such as Sarbanes-Oxley, voluntary tax preparation programs, taxpayer services and the ever-improving technology enhances the likelihood of a successful tax return.
As the November 2002 elections fade further into memory, it's time for taxpayers to get organized. Even if the transfer of power brings a new administration, there are precious few who can be for or against taxes without a base of taxation

What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal gesture of poetry and quail at the potential narcissism of the poet who attempts to speak for humanity. In a world made miserable, the political will say, there is no integrity  in  the  individual, in the poet’s self-expression. Should a poem fail to acknowledge the situation–antiseptically labeled "conflict" in order to grant dehumanized victims a vague pity–then its language must be cruelly dismissed as a cowardly abdication of the task of civic life.

Air strikes conducted near Erbil and the Mosul dam amid reports of mass killings by Sunni fighters in Syria.
The United States has conducted air strikes in Iraq against the Islamic State goup amid reports that the group's fighters are conducting a campaign of mass killings in Syria.
The strikes late on Saturday and early on Sunday near Erbil targeted areas Kurdish forces had lost control of to the group after they fled the reach of Iraqi government security forces.
In a statement the Pentagon said it had dispatched the six F-16 planes and some drones after deeming it a necessary military operation to halt the advance of the group following its seizure of the Mosul Dam.
Earlier on Saturday the group's fighters issued a grisly video of the destruction earlier in the day of a Shia mosque in the Tigress east of Mosul, Saba pledging further attacks.
The group also controls the Islamic State in Syria (ISIS) and occupied large swaths of territory in Syria making large scale atrocities possible.

LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, does not cause cancer, a European food safety watchdog body said on Thursday.
The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) pesticide unit said that the finding was independent of a legal battle between Bayer (BAYG.DE), which owns Monsanto, and the U.S. state of California over use of the chemical.
“In conclusion, the pesticide safety committee found no risk to overall human health — the general population, as well as infants and children — from exposure to glyphosate through the diet,” the EFSA said in a statement.
EFSA’s glyphosate working group had in 2015 been split over the conclusions, which partly echoed a similar U.S. finding.
A court case on California’s “no record of significant harm” warning policy was to begin in March in San Francisco.

APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 58, who is the third longest tenured news organization executive in the state, announced his plan to retire Feb. 9, about six months after the Pulitzer Prize unexpectedly announced Jim Stratman as managing editor. Soon after the transition, Stratman announced Bunde Schalk as his replacement.
Berthiaume said his decision to retire consists of him returning to his former newspaper roots and following his dream of writing a novel.
"The plan is to write a novel. ... My wife kind of bribed me to retire with the nudge of saying she just really, really wants me to do this. We're talking about me writing a trashy novel and she's going to edit it," Berthiaume said. "Now I'm no IT expert, but I'm going to figure it out and make a go of it."

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. As a Platonizing Neoplatonist, he was fully aware of the conflict between Plato and Aristotle which we have examined in the present volume [p. 144]. His energies and his abilities were devoted to a mediation between the two philosophical currents. After the break with Christianity, it must be supposed that in the beliefs of Christian theologians, the idea of the eternal de jure divino had already broken free from the Platonizing orientation [p. 74]. With the rise of the powerful Arab intellectual culture, of which the Islam of the Arabic Middle Ages formed an important expressive element [p. 88], dogmatic Platonism reached a dogmatic peak. Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton had just declared victory in the Nevada caucuses when most campaign reporters heard Jeffrey Berman’s voice for the first and only time.
Berman, Sen. Barack Obama’s national media director, was taking the first unfiltered victory swipe at the woman you’ve come to know so well, her victories so far relatively modest despite the attention they have commanded.
“We won walking away. One hundred percent of precincts are now in, and Barack Obama has now won 14 delegate equivalent awards more than Hillary Clinton,” Berman said into his cell phone in New Hampshire, directly after the former first lady had announced her own figures.
We struck up a brief conversation recently in New Hampshire. As you might expect from a man who calls Hillary Clinton’s staff phone numbers on a regular basis, he is feisty, blunt and directive. I found him both irritating and delightful at times.

I am compelled to get the word out regarding a Senate bill that could adversely affect private preschools in California. The bill is labeled SB 837 or Kindergarten Readiness Act of 2014.
On the surface, SB 837 looks like a great idea. We all want "kindergarten-ready" kindergartners. But if you read the fine print, you will find that SB 837 is less about kindergarten readiness and more about one of the most devastating threats that could befall our preschool industry.
Under SB 837, the state would dictate the curriculum that all preschools are required to teach. For example, all preschools would be required to include certain types of social studies curriculum and other curricula deemed appropriate by the state. Likewise, kids in preschool would be required to demonstrate certain things on a kindergarten-prep exam.

Metaphysics special: Do we have free will?
“DID I really just decide to have fish and chips for lunch?” Humans have been wrestling with such questions for millennia. Maybe not about the fish and chips — although there are philosophical questions around the consumption of anchovy patties — but definitely about human free will and its limitations.
Despite being one of the oldest mysteries of the universe, no definitive answer to the question of agency is accepted as fact just yet. However, categorically nowhere in the science, whether in human behaviour, genetics, or the fundamental nature of the universe itself, are there solid lines drawn. There are endless studies into the sub-atomic world, the human mind, and plain old boredom, and the sum fundamental response to all of these factors appears to be the same as the human response to a Zen koan: although you know your own opinion, you’re never going to be able to convince anyone else of it.

Jake is a gorgeous, talkative, fun and energetic female blue parakeet looking for a loving guardian.
Jake flew into the backyard of a family in Chicago and landed on a man's shoulder while the man was sitting on the lawn.
The man, who spoke with Jake, said she seemed happy and healthy.
As the family was leaving they realized Jake had been with them the entire time sitting on the man's shoulder so they quickly snapped a picture.
A kind neighbor said the bird did not have a band on and that she had never seen a sick or injured bird do the exact same thing!
It is unique for a stray bird to take a such a positive liking to one person right off the bat.
This is known as a "chimney effect", which occurs when a bird returns to the exact place when becoming distressed to find themselves in the same environment which was previously a safe place where they felt comfortable.
Not only does Jake have a feather missing, there are noticeable bald spots from which she patches with new feathers.
She has short feathered feet

A memorial service is planned for Fort Bragg City Councilman Jere Melo at 2 p.m. Sept. 10 at the Timberwolf Stadium on Chestnut Street in Fort Bragg.
He died Aug. 24 from complications of a diabetic illness, according to his family.
Melo was born in the Bronx, New York, but after his father was laid off during the 1960s, he moved with his family to Southern California where he attended school at the University of Southern California. He was a standout athlete at Santa Ana College where he earned an Associate's degree in administration of justice.
In 1980, he married Gigi Phelps. They moved to Fort Bragg after he bought FM station KZFR from the original owners, and he moved on to the ABC affiliate, KSRO and KQED, the Bay Area's public television station.
Melo worked in Fort Bragg at KZFR until 2006.
"He was the kind of guy that kept me out of jail so many times!"

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It is most commonly used to treat lung and throat infections such as pneumonia and tonsillitis. It can also treat skin and soft tissue infections, such as cellulitis and wound infections. It can also be used to prevent tonsillitis in children aged 2 months and older when other treatments have failed to prevent infections. Clarithromycin is also available in combination with other medications for the treatment of infections.
Combination medication: Clarithromycin can be combined with other antibiotics in order to increase its effectiveness. The combination medication is also effective in treating bacterial infections.

Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, leading to a more acidic ocean with elevated carbon dioxide.
As a result, shell-producing organisms, including plankton and smaller creatures ingested by fish, are less active compared to preindustrial times, according to a new study by Penn State researchers published in Deep Sea Research II: Topical Studies in Oceanography late last month.
This phenomenon is causing drastic effects on plankton population size in ocean regions known as the "twilight zone," situated in a subsurface zone below the ocean sunlight limit, but above the ocean's twilight zone -- an area normally characterized by minimal amounts of photosynthesis due to decreased sunlight.

Quanell X did not respond to a phone call from KHOU-TV seeking comment on the lawsuit.

The Turkish decision to expel the ambassador from Ankara came after Israel had announced it would block the Turkish flotilla. Tributes have been paid to young Teesside mum Laura Hodgson who has lost her fight for life.
Laura, from Billingham , was diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer last year.
The mum of a one-year-old had previously battled the disease on a single-occasion before she had her gall bladder removed last month while her cancer went into remission.
But her condition has taken a turn for the worse and Laura is now under special care in King’s Hospital in London.
Now her family are appealing for donations to the Laura Hodgson Fund, so family and friends can travel to her side during her final battle.
Dad Scott attended the appeal on Saturday and met kind-hearted donors while Laura and mother Susan spoke to the Gazette about the family’s heartbreaking ordeal.
“We have all had a real specially week, some precious time with Laura. We have seen her fighting, giving birth to number one grandchild Mason,” said mum Susan.
“Things started badly. We were led to believe the cancer had spread to the bone and everyone had to pull together.

A hoax Facebook virus is spreading rapidly across the social network.
Many users have been hoodwinked into forwarding an inaccurate warning about the spread of non-existent malware that claims a girl committed suicide because of it.
So how has this false message gained traction by so many? The situation jumps on one of social networking's key characteristics of message forwards - the chance to mindlessly forward a message without a second thought.
Users can get a false sense that by forwarding the message they are doing good, stopping the spread of an awful virus or malware that could compromise their computer. Another factor is how easy it is to just press a button to 'like' the hoax or to forward a message without the user doing any real analysis, which can also breeds trustworthiness.
How to forward While this malicious scam typically claims to be a virus on the system it is actually a malicious hoax spread through Facebook. Virus hoax messages are typically mistaken for a system virus due to the fact that you must host the file on your system after downloading in order to infect someone else with that system viruses.

McChord, who started the online security company Datto in 2007 in his father's basement, will step down as CEO.
McChord, who started the online security company in 2007 in his father's basement, said he wanted to spend more time with his family and on personal projects.
"After more than a decade as CEO at Datto, I am taking the time this year to reflect and further define my own role in the company and also serve my family and home communities in Connecticut and Florida," he said in a statement.
The Norwalk-based company's past board members include Kevin Vitale, executive vice president at First Republic Bank, Joseph Juliano, executive vice president and treasurer at PayPal, actress and former U.S. Ambassador to Ireland Nicole Kidman and Boston College basketball coach Jim Christian.
The company is based in Norwalk but also has offices in Boston, Dallas and Orlando, Fla.
Datto says it provides more than 160,000 small businesses with cloud-based backup, security, recovery and business continuity solutions.

Prime Minister Manmohan Singh in his monthly radio show 'Mann Ki Baat' had recently told citizens that the Jan Lokpal bill should be passed by the government with the recommendations of the joint committee of all party MPs.
"In the recently-concluded monsoon session of parliament, the government had intended to pass the Lut yagnopavit bill. However, the government has succeeded in doing the opposite. People are reacting strongly against fraud and wrong policies. The satyagraha will also express the strong views of people," Srinta district marker Ashok Jena said. Ashok also warned protesters to withdraw the movement or they would face violent crackdown.
Hazare has been holding protests over the issue of enacting a strong Lokpal Bill in the recently-concluded monsoon session, but the government didn't listen to him and the bill was merely passed in the last meeting.

When and where does the Torchlight Procession take place?
In recent years the Torchlight Procession has been the Saturday before New Year's Eve (which is a Monday), so if you've seen it take place on the Sunday, don't worry, you've seen the right one.
In 2018 the procession will take place on Saturday 30 December.
The procession set off from the Meadows, making its way to George Square (and will continue to do so in 2019, so you don't have to worry about where the start location is).
The procession sees thousands of can-holding locals and guests descend upon the city ready to celebrate the end of the year.
After the torches have been extinguished and the bells have rung midnight, the cans will then get the full Hogmanay experience with one big party taking place in the streets.

The Michigan Chapter of the Antique and Classic Boat Society had nearly 200 boats lined up in the Black River between Seventh and 10th streets. The previous record for an ACBS International Boat Show was 170 boats.
A camera drone swirled the boats in final preparation for the show.
Boats sat alongside the Lootens Dock on the canalside above the Riverwalk.
Many boats were poised along the river with the City Historic District in the background.
Riverwalk visitors walked around the birchbark canoe, a passenger canoe at Fountain Gate and the Enterprise, Captain Charles Wilcox’s river dragger.
But the wind did not keep boaters from sailing into the Chicago River. Tern boats, with streamers, wove their masts in the patches of sky above the Lootens Dock.
Casual vacationers checked out canoes, rowboats, sailboats and Gorman Maines fishing craft.
A rainbow covered the Riverwalk as a castaway canoe made its way down the Chicago River.

Christian formation is the lifelong process of growing in our relationship with God, self, others, and all creation. Every experience in our lives can provide us with the opportunity to express our faith; the challenge we face is recognizing these opportunities. Our lives are really wrapped up in the rich mysteries of creation and human experience, and these invite us into a lifelong journey of discovery and learning. Being a Christian is a whole way of life, and it can't be fully explained in a classroom or a worship setting.
Christian formation invites us into a covenantal relationship with God. It is a companionable, life-long process of living in a timeless, trusting relationship with God. This experience provides us with the opportunity to experience the infinite mystery of God’s presence through the full variety of human experiences.
We seek to provide a rich variety of opportunities for Christian formation at Camp Towana (and through Camp Towano.) CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Abdul Latif, a columnist for the luxury borders outdoor magazine Information Age, was taken into custody after publishing a book online calling for the replacement of decades-old subsidy policies.
His wife, Amira, the editor of the magazine, said her husband had refused police attempts to make him remove the book and he had also recently been threatened by a prominent security official with a tie to the interior ministry.
Economists have slammed Egypt's subsidies policies as siphoning away scarce cash and exacerbating poverty.
The government denies the policies are a burden on the economy and says they are directed towards the poor.
Recent violence against ministries or security directorates over subsidies have prompted the authorities to take security measures and put the country on high alert.

Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this question should demonstrate that you know the company and what you can offer. Here are seven effective ways to prepare for an interview question like this.
Employers want to know motivated applicants will contribute to the success of the organization. Gather information about the company during your interview preparation. Find out the company mission statement, along with its objectives, goals, and overall vision. Describe how you can develop as a professional and contribute to the achievement of the company's objectives.
Hiring managers want successful candidates who can think outside the box and solve problems. Describe how your skills have enabled you to solve problems in the past. This is also a chance to talk about your objectivity and how you can work with a diverse group. Discuss how you can handle weaknesses, such as becoming bored or falling behind when you have trouble seeing the big picture. Give examples demonstrating how you handled a challenging situation during a project or an experience

Acadiana has become known as the home of family friendly Mardi Gras — drawing crowds of more than 300,000 from around the nation and the world.

Dave Eggers' history as the motive force behind the experimental, expectations-challenging literary-goofery platform McSweeney's hangs heavily over his new book, What Is The What. Simultaneously wanted by theaters, a major movie studio, and a small independent publisher, Eggers admits the title proved the most daunting weapons of the battle over the rights to the story.
It's understandable, especially with the juicy conflict over the rights fluffing the propulsive train of his storytelling. You just barely have time to pop the hood on the subject matter — so obviously rich with pathos — before the train is barreling full-bore towards unspeakable human tragedy in the Sudanese civil war.
It's a daunting task for any writer, particularly one with none of the experience (and some might say, none of the language) that can be had to effectively sift through the ensuing emotion of the story. At the least, What Is The What is a simple but moving story.

Your credit card company doesn't have your best interests at heart.
Credit cards have caused financial pain for millions of consumers. It's easy to run up a balance, but as too many people find out the hard way, trying to get out from under a pile of debt can be just as difficult. Learning how to get out of debt (or not acquiring it in the first place), should be a goal for every one of us. Here are a few tips on how to deal with credit cards if you or a loved one is in over their head.
Before making any big decisions, you have to have a plan of action. A good rule of thumb is to only charge what you can pay off in one payment, and never carry a balance from one month to the next. If this means you are going to have to make sacrifices, so be it. Take a second job or cut as many expenses as you can out of your monthly budget. If your credit card bills are so large that you can't possibly hope to pay them off soon, the first thing you should do is contact your credit card company, explain your financial situation and ask for a lower interest

Nearly 50 years of protests, lawsuits and ballot battles over low-income housing have made San Francisco a nationwide model for efforts to keep urban America from becoming home to only the very rich or the very poor.
The results are undeniable. Tenants with the means to do so have made the decision to live in San Francisco, while residents with more modest means have moved elsewhere.
The percentage of the population living below the poverty level climbed from 9.9 percent in the 1970 census to 15.3 percent in the latest one.
In the last decade, especially, the biggest growth in the ranks of the poor has been among families of more than four children. From 1999 to the most recent tax records, the number of families earning below the 200 percent poverty level more than doubled and are now 50 percent of San Francisco’s estimated 204,100.
Poverty has a clearer correlation with the city’s population decline than higher housing prices. The percentages are virtually the inverse.

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden in December 1898.
It was discovered a few months ago on a beach on Kerrera in the Inner Hebrides, around 7km (4 miles) from Oban, the Western Isles Association (WIA) said.
The small vessel, who had alerted the coastguard, was a fishing boat that had towed a rowing boat belonging to a small group of visiting school boys, they explained.
Boats had just been released after normal Post Office inspections and the WIA said the message was on a harmless orange coloured soda bottle - with a 'removable screwcap' - the provenance of which had not yet been confirmed.

The Narromine Garden Club have gifted their annual donation to local organisation the Narromine Volunteer Rescue Association (VRA). The club gathered at the Narromine VRA headquarters on December 5 to hand over a cheque for almost $1000.
The Narromine Garden Club have gifted their annual donation to local organisation the Narromine Volunteer Rescue Association (VRA).
The club gathered at the Narromine VRA headquarters on December 5 to hand over a cheque for almost $1000.
The group have made the donation for the past six years, making a total of just under $6000.
The Narromine Garden Club have a long history with the Narromine VRA, with the vice president Debbie Jackson’s husband Ian also a member.
Narromine Garden Club Committee Secretary Virginia Morgan said the group originally decided to make the donation to the local rescue services after the Babadong bushfire.
As well as a monetary donation, the garden club also donates garden beds filled with native trees, shrubs and flowers each year.

Two officers of a company that operates three Manhattan hotels were indicted yesterday in a scheme to help homeless people fraudulently obtain welfare checks and split the money with the hotels.
District Attorney Robert S. Johnson said that the officers and 10 other defendants conspired to cash up to 1000 checks every month. A spokesman for the district attorney's office said that some of the defendants accepted cash to cash and endorse welfare checks that have been signed by people who never actually cash them.
The scheme usually consisted of calling a hotel operator or the person cashing the check and going over the security number on the check with the caller. An innocent party would then deliver the welfare check to the address of the hotel, the spokesman said. If the hotel called in the welfare check number, the defendants examined the name on the welfare check. Then a hotel employee would call one of the defendants, whose job was to sneak the welfare check out of the hotel or into the hotel and cash the check with the hotel operator'

Did van Gogh cut off his ear because his brother was engaged?
AMSTERDAM - New evidence has bolstered a theory that Vincent van Gogh's psychotic break on Dec 23, 1888, was triggered by his excessive jealousy of Theo buying his wedding ring the day before.
Van Gogh, who had recently moved from Paris to southern France to be near Theo, cut off his left ear and gouged out one of the eyes with a pen-knife the morning of the wedding.
Shortly afterwards, he was admitted into the Provence asylum.
In the ensuing turmoil at the nuptials in the small town of Nuenen - Theo had bought his wedding ring the day before 'with special orders to be let into the back of the parsonage, where the couple were practicing a piano concerto - Van Gogh left with 'only the stump of his ear'.

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies own their own servers, many smaller providers only have a limited number of servers to rent server space to clients. This means they rent interior server space to people looking for web hosting services.
People can save a substantial amount of money when purchasing web servers directly from a large site rather than going through a reseller as a middleman. However, some find it harder to deal with a large company directly, and prefer to have a reseller act as the intermediary. By cutting out some of the middleman expenses, a reseller can earn a much smaller cut than the actual hosting web site. This means more money saved for the client, and more profit for the reseller.
Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?

WASHINGTON — The unemployment rate fell to 3.7 percent, the U.S. Labor Department announced Friday.
An estimated 600,000 jobs were created last month, more than economists anticipated.
Average hourly earnings rose by 3.1 percent from the year prior.
Economists say the monthly jobs report shows “a solid economy.”
Contractors are seeking workers and paying good money for them.
For the seventh consecutive month, average hourly earnings increased.
The Labor Department did numerous revisions to the monthly jobs figures from September to October, restoring part-time jobs to the labor market in September.
That means the increase is more happening in the part-time labor force, which is a good sign for the middle class, he added.

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national Neonatal Mortality Rate – or the number of babies who do not survive the first 28 days after birth – decreased from 6.67 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in 2000 to 5.16 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in 2010, a 23% reduction.
But that improvement levled out in the last few years with a six-year average of 5.20 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in 2007-12, compared to 5.10 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in 2013-17.
The reasons for this increase are unclear, the study authors reported, but could be attributed to increasing maternal age

The Public Service Commission on Wednesday approved a pilot program intended to create up to 350 megawatts of long-term renewable power within the next three years, a move that state officials and environmentalists say could help expedite North Carolina’s renewable-energy goal.
Under the three-year program, the Utility Commission can purchase clean energy from a certain kind of renewable energy certification.
During the same time frame, the Commission also can purchase power from a town or county wind farm, a senior living community, an apartment complex, zero-emissions military facilities or new privately owned solar facilities in the Tar Heel state.
“These are the places where you will have the greatest impact in the numbers for the greatest wattage due to their ability to access capital,” said Matthew Lusk, a conservation advocate with the Southern Environmental Center at North Carolina State University.
Amy Jackson, project coordinator for the Southeastern Energy Efficiency Alliance, agreed.
“Those are the projects we're excited to see rolling out so we can contract with them before demand ends in December,” Jackson said.

Earth requires fuel to drive plate tectonics, volcanoes and its magnetic field. Like a hybrid car, Earth taps two sources of energy to run its engine: primordial energy from assembling the planet and nuclear energy from the sun. Formed 4.6 billion years ago during the accretion of the early solar system, Earth's supply of primordial (thermal) nuclear energy is limited, so the sun (electrical) powers only a small fraction of Earth's energetic output.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as fibroblasts appear to work together to send a signal to the micro-environment around a cell to limit the growth or damage of genetic changes to the DNA.
The discovery — made using live fur-coated adult elephants, excised kidney and heart cells from a deceased elephant, and engineered human skin fibroblast cells — could unlock the ability to identify early stages of tumors and possibly the most effective drugs to fight them.
“That means elephants can regulate pre-cancerous structures in the same way that they can regulate wounds,” study author Irina Conboy, professor of bioengineering and therapeutic sciences at the University of California, Berkley, said.

New analysis shows 22 of Australia’s largest companies are actively working to undermine the Paris agreement targets, betting shareholders’ money on strategies that assume global climate change action fails.
Investor action group Market Forces took a closer look at the emissions profile of the 200 biggest S&P/ASX200 companies – more than half (112) of which have an emissions intensity above the Paris Agreement of 55 grams of carbon dioxide per dollar of revenue.

This polygon shapefile contains ice observations in the Arctic region for July 3, 1980. This layer is part of the Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive. The earliest chart in the data set comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by Sir Hugh AC, returned to England. Their ships were carried southwards on ice floes, and came close to the voyage's objective, the mouth of the river that today bears their name, the Chany. The next chart is from 1650, when least squares linear regressions were used to estimate the general movement of the ice edge, derived from matrices of ordinal ice-edge positions across wide regions. These regressions made it possible to determine the general movement of the ice in the entire Arctic Ocean a decade at a time. The dataset indicates that the ice condition was stable between 1550 and 1850, despite fluctuations. Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemicals at a time when they cost more and have become a hot issue. And using compost as mulch is one of the time-tested, no-brainer ways to get your yard to look its best immediately.
One of the needs most commonly neglected in the spirit of saving time and money is getting our beds ready for spring. Adding compost to the bed not only improves the texture and drainage, but also provides the growing medium that holds onto soaks and feeds the young roots of plants for some time to come. Compost is a potent aid to raising vigorous, nourished soybeans and other crops.
Although the evidence speaks for itself, some consumers new to composting have questions about both the safety and the efficacy of the product. We will talk about the safety in the moment, but should begin with the efficacy of the product.

It takes a lot to make me feel ashamed of London, my beloved home city. But yesterday’s tower-block inferno did it. The raging fire at Grenfell Tower in North Kensington, the disturbing image of people leaping 11 storeys into the night sky, the casual tales of people charging with their bags through the smoke — all this should have been a huge collective scandal resulting in collective politicalfallout.
And the political fallout is indeed taking place. Mr May’s hands are trembling at the thought that this will permanently jeopardise her moment of history when she becomes the Mother Of All Prime Ministers, the prize patiently won during ten years in the shadow cabinet.
So she is hired quickly into the role of ‘one nation’ politician in white British suburbia and the ‘progressive’ superstructure of the Parliamentary Conservative Party, above all by the constant spectre of the furious humanity released on the wind in the smoke.
As I write this (Sunday), the inhabitants of the tower block are still trapped amid the remains we have come to know too well.

Alaska's distilleries can no longer serve mixed drinks to customers, the state agency overseeing alcohol ruled Tuesday.
In a 3-1 vote, the Alcoholic Beverage Control announcing an end to the program. Regulators said it was deceptive to call a distillery and order a mixed drink when such a transaction cannot take place, so the agency ordered state-licensed businesses to close the practice Tuesday.
A handful of other states allow distilleries to make cocktails for immediate consumption — California has the most at 55, according to a 2018 study published by the Wall Street Journal — but Alaska is the only one currently allowing mixed drinks to be served with a license.
Distributors can still get a mixed drink license that allows them to call a bar and order a cocktail made with a bar's liquor instead of bottled liquor, but most do not use the license.

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., said his daughter Maya.
Karnow's acclaimed work on Vietnam, "Very Long War," won a National Book Award in the hybrid category more than 30 years ago and remains the standard history of the U.S. involvement in Indochina. Vietnamese students and war veterans say it is a better source of information than the writings of journalists such as David Halberstam or author Tim O'Brien.
Karnow, who enjoyed a diverse and successful journalism career, abandoned plans for a medical profession after the start of World War II in Europe. He wrote for the Nation magazine in Portland, Ore. A report by the Wall Street Journal suggests that Dell could be on the verge of becoming a public company once again.
The deal could be announced as soon as later today and -- if the cited sources close to Dell are correct -- the $25 billion sale would slash Dell's debt by half.
The once-revered PC and server maker became a private entity in September of 2013 when it went public with a $25 billion, special dividend buyout. The creation of the new company meant the removal of all public shareholders.
Dell reported revenues of $58.8 billion-$60.7 billion for 2018.
The deal is reportedly valued at some $21 billion plus its $10 billion cash on hand. The sale price would slash the company's debt from more than $40 billion in total.
Dell announced earlier that it will cancel its fourth quarter earnings call due to the "significant market" momentum and instead reach employees via a video message that debut on the company's YouTube channel.

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals identify the potential impact of the options they consider with a task. The diagram shows the consequences of a decision – the probability of the decisions' outcomes, while a summary at the base of the tree shows the possible actions to take when each decision is made.
Uses of Decision Trees
Decision trees are common in capital budgeting, with investors considering investment proposals that affect cash flow. One example of a decision tree uses is with an investor approving a capital project, choosing a particular lender for a project and assessing the impact to cash flow. At the other end of the financial scale, a financial advisor could show an entire lifetime investment strategy in the form of a decision tree.

Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered towards the mine around noon (0500 GMT) on Saturday after heavy rainfall, according to Sama Le Min Min, a local official.
At least a dozen people are feared buried – including a Jackson Mayit, a photographer caught in the landslide with his brother, Khet Mayit, a miner.
Yangbay Lawu, 45, said the men had trekked down the mountainside to collect jade quartz, a form of the gemstone prized in China and around the world.
"Around 7 pm (1200 GMT), a rocklide poured down the mine after the rain in the evening," Lawu, the mine boss, told AFP by telephone.

Busan (South Korea) (AFP) - A Korean drama about desperate teens and a movie that exposes the hardships of daily life in the Iranian capital Tehran shared the top prize at Asia's premier movie festival in the southern port city of Busan.
Entitled "Deliver Us From Evil", the 100-minute film wows audiences with a dark and violent take on a budding matchmaking scene involving the precariat - a newly created class of people outside the protection offered by both tradition and sheer capitalism.
It premiered at the Busan International Film Festival (BIFF) last week.
Its director, Hong Eui-jeong, who portrayed the hallucinations the protagonists suffer after witnessing a homicide within the HWANGA, a vast slum by the waterfront, explained why the story is so powerful.
"TIME and space are serious issues dealing with a lack of time and space for the precariat," said one attendee after the screening.

Everyone went nuts for Adobe’s “content-aware fill” in Photoshop when it came out. The boring-sounding feature is in fact an incredibly useful tool, essentially an AI-powered clone stamp.
Due to limitations with the technology, though, the clone stamp had to be applied to an image that you had obviously already imported, which introduced a fair amount of unnecessary steps into the process of editing. Adobe fixed this with the introduction of a content-aware tool that only required you to paint a brushstroke over a section of an image to generate a fill, but it still had limitations. Images needed to be in a rectangular shape in order to utilize the tool correctly.
How to Use Photoshop’s Content-Aware Fill to Quickly

Pat had everything a person could want of any life—loyalty, lifetime achievements in the performing arts, gigs until the end—and yet never truly seemed to achieve all but a means to an end.
At worst, a cursory: Even after a lifetime of supporting a family on the bare essentials writing and performing with his own voice, a career that was also a form of activism since the age of seventeen and responsible for various degrees of a range of successes the world over, Pat had a bucket list that looked more or less like this: Make enough money to let other people do what they want to do for a living, and let this music play right

The Campaign for Liberty, a libertarian advocacy group founded by congressman and presidential candidate Ron Paul (R-TX), is campaigning against three bills on Capitol Hill, asserting that the proposed legislation encroaches on individual privacy.
The group is particularly concerned over Federal Aviation Administration reauthorization debates and debates revolving around Internet copyright policy.
The FAA reauthorization, the Campaign for Liberty says, would strengthen the federal government’s control over the digital age by allowing the government to listen in on wireless Internet signals coming from private citizens and to censor any content with which the government objected.
Likewise, the Campaign for Liberty is calling on individuals to contact their representatives in Congress to oppose the Stop Online Piracy Act (SOPA) and the Protect IP Act (PIPA).

UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon has been re-elected to serve a second five-year term, in a vote at the UN General Assembly.
Mr Ban, a South Korean national, beat the other two candidates, Prince Zeid al-Hussein of Jordan and Abdulatif Abdelrahman el-Fakih of Libya.
Mr Ban, 67, began his first term in office just two months after the September 11 attacks, and had always planned to limit his second term to a single five-year period.
U2's Bono cast the deciding vote in favour of him on the 197th ballot.
The UN Security Council is expected to formally re-elect him on Thursday.
During his speech recognising his re-election, Mr Ban thanked all 192 member states of the UN General Assembly for their trust.

A. Annual income may have decreased more than your annuity benefit. This usually occurs when the average lifespan of the insured (like mine) exceeds the average duration of the plan. Because of the length of your plan, 10 years, the hundreds of policies in the insurance company's reserves are probably below the average age/life span for your plan years.
An annuity is a liability of the insurance company and a liability! If the life span for your plan were the normal 7 years, you would receive a higher payment. A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot tempers.
The study, published this week in the Journal of Marriage and Family, compared how well couples reported getting along with their own paternal grandmas with how well they coped with some typically stressful everyday situations. “Our study demonstrates that being one’s female grandparental grandchild could be a crucial ingredient in the recipe for happiness in these marital relationships,” said Paul Abramson, a research scientist at The Kinsey Institute and one of the study’s authors.
Photo: Google Images.
Using five different measures – from relationship satisfaction to how much the so-called “blessers” helped with childcare and the household – the researchers found that women who had a positive relationship with their maternal grandmother significantly reduced their likelihood of experiencing increased conflict with their male partner while handling a stressful situation. Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given -- just one of the many benefits of buying a commercial application.
But the small- and midsize-business (SMB) world is traditionally wonderfully heterogeneous, with vendors often offering a handful of legacy applications, all integrated with a wide array of others without deep disclosure of how the main application actually works. Its source code tends to be viewed as the Holy Grail of ERP vendors to be kept in a vault at the vendor's headquarters.
A few other applications, traditionally made available only to large enterprises with a 100-employee, $100 million GEO (global equivalent of Revenue plus Orders), are the subject of a COBOL juggernaut at large companies -- largely IBM plc's Power Systems line, mainframes powered by Unix and attached to a corporate "message broker."

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) — Treasury prices extended their pullback Tuesday, propelling the government debt market to its fourth day of losses in five sessions, after data showed service-sector companies expanded at a quickened pace during the month of March.
A gain in equities, with financial shares aiding the advance, curbed data-driven demand for Treasurys. Tracking the 20-year Treasury yield, the government debt market has shed more than a quarter-percent from the highs set just two sessions ago, though it remains further into the upside than downside so far this year after factoring in a muted start to 2013.
“Pickups [from data] can always be a cause of some concern on the [longer] end of the curve. Even if it’s a minor move,” said Jack Kconigion, vice president and trader at Milford Asset Management, who sees the treasury curve shifting into a flattening trend, as yields on the short and intermediate ends rise while the long end yields come in.

Lyft has pulled from service all of its on-demand electric bicycles in New York, Washington DC and the San Francisco Bay area after some riders reported issues with the brakes.
"We recently received a small number of reports from riders about some on-demand electric bikes with malfunctioning brakes," Lyft said in a statement sent to Axios. "Although the pool of affected bikes is small, we have taken the precautionary step to immediately remove these vehicles from the streets."
Why it matters: Labelling the concerns a "minor issue," the company said the repairs are underway. "We continue to work with our partners to ensure the fleet is properly maintained and these kinds of issues don't happen again," the company continued.
Electric bikes are the latest hit in a string of transportation and safety concerns for ride-hailing services in the United States. MEXICO CITY (AP) — A man was arrested Monday in the shooting death of a journalist who worked for the newspaper El Heraldo de Chiapas, and authorities were searching for three other people suspected of having ordered it, just hours after a separate journalist was killed in the key western state of Sinaloa.
El Heraldo de Chiapas reported the arrest of Fabián Ávila Santillán, a citizen of the state of Chihuahua. No other details were provided about his arrest.
Imperial Vice Prosecutor Carlos Nava Vázquez explained that a warrant had been issued on July 2 for three other unidentified people related to the assassination of journalist Hildalgo Aníbal Moreno Gómez.
Authorities said in a statement the three men had ordered the assassination of Moreno Gómez because they were angry with the journalist for allegedly causing injuries to a relative in an automobile wreck.

Gene Blevins/ReutersA tornado in Kansas last week. A new poll suggests the public feels that global warming is real.
Sunday will be the 42nd annual Earth Day celebration. Here are six important things to know about the history of the event.
President Jimmy Carter established the first Earth Day, an environmental teach-in at college campuses across the country, on April 22, 1970.
The purpose was to force Americans to focus on their effects on the earth: "We rob the Earth first, and then compound the theft with the destruction of the air and water on which all life depends."
Other than that, Earth Day, which now defines a global event, has slowly and quietly evolved into a celebration of mother earth to be enjoyed by every human regardless of age, race, gender or religion.
In a poll published in The Hill on Thursday, more than half of Americans (56 percent) reported feeling that global warming is real.

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to the country’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, did not disclose the location of the second uranium enrichment facility or the exact size of the new plant. The newspaper said the facility used a more modern design referred to in Iran as the IR-6.
That plant has been denounced by Tehran’s enemies — the United States and its allies — as “weapons grade uranium.”
Ever since the nuclear deal with world powers collapsed in May, Tehran has challenged the West to take one more concrete step — remove International Atomic Energy Agency, or IAEA — sniffer dogs from three Iranian military sites that inspectors have long wanted access to, most notably the Parchin site.
