The mayor tried to rush through a complicated proposal that caught too many Kansas City leaders by surprise. James enthusiastically presented his broad outline to the Kansas City Council with the hope of getting his proposal on the November ballot. He was met with a reluctant reception. Other than a few supporters of the idea, James' bill nearly died that session. He left the bill with Ward 3 Councilman John Sharp as the assistant majority leader without strong written recommendations from the powerful Finance committee.
When the bill returned the next year the committee voted unanimously to recommend the measure go into a committee of the whole—a hearing before the full council where some discussion occurred before a decision is issued—instead of a full confirmation vote. James sank the task for the time being and the issue did not become a major point of contention again until a few months ago. The legislative session had practically a dozen more proposals jockeying for limiting spending than James' bill.
The new controversy came from a petition signed by more than 850 people that will put the issue back on the ballot for the May 2006 election.

ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, complicating a boardroom struggle for control. The Swiss mobile operator announced the proposed extension on Monday along with a deal to buy smaller rival Salt's fiber assets.
Sunrise, backed by wealthy representatives of the Zumtaugwald clan, plans to vie for Swisscom , the country's largest telecoms operator.
On Monday, the family's head Gualtiero Zumtaugwald called the extension an unnecessary burden on a business that had a strong momentum and was not in agreement with how its board ceased power.
"We require an extended information period in order to review the consequences of the plans detailed in the Sunrise Capital announcement," he wrote in a letter addressed to the board of directors.
The decision over the capital plan was made late in the evening of March 29 and "completely contradicted the mandate given by the general meeting", he wrote.

Marvel Studios President Kevin Feige has big plans for the Marvel Cinematic Universe following 2019's Avengers 4 - over a dozen, in fact.
"[Marvel is] 22 movies in and we have announced 10 more," Feige told Collider during the press day for Avengers: Infinity War. "So we are pretty much close to the 30-and-a-quarter-movie mark there, of something that we are calling Phase Three. Let's call [what's to come] Phase Four."

Davis said the ways people treat their clothes often says more about the messages we take from the world than the shoes and jackets themselves.
“Clothing provides a powerful method of communication that delivers measurements of the history, economics, gender roles, religion and ideology of the people who make and own it,” Davis wrote in her book.
The clothing of those stranded on the Brooklyn side of the Manhattan bridge in 2003 showed more of their circumstances than the economic system they lived in, she said.
Their clothing also said a great deal about the New York (and national) political system they lived in.

According to a report issued by the Pew Research Center, American adults have a sub-par knowledge of basic science. The organization surveyed 3,278 Americans of various social, racial and academic backgrounds. The questionnaire consisted of 12 multiple-choice questions, and those who answered seven or less correctly were deemed to have a ‘below basic’ knowledge of the subject.
Only 13% of Americans were deemed ‘proficient’ in the survey, meaning they answered at most three of the questions incorrectly. Another 25% of respondents had a ‘basic’ knowledge of the subject and 28% had a ‘low’ level of scientific knowledge; answering five or fewer questions correctly fell under this category. 20% of Americans surveyed had a ‘very poor’ scientific knowledge and those who answered all 12 questions incorrectly made up a whopping 9% of the sample size.

Sudan: Military Leadership Challenged by Ongoing Protests | Democracy Now!
In Sudan, the head of the newly installed military council resigned Friday, just one day after he was sworn in following the ouster of autocrat President Omar al-Bashir. Army deputy chief of staff General Mohammed Hamdan, also known as Hemedti, replaced Abdel Fatta Ahmed al-Burhan as the military council chief. Hemedti is a close ally of al-Bashir and ran spoiler campaigns in the 2015 referendum to join Sudan with the South Sudan through a specially endorsed referendum in the capital. A previous deal between the military leadership and protesters also included the transition of power from al-Bashir to a joint civilian and military council last week. The protesters had demanded the removal of the military leadership from their transition plan.

Insight: Did Conficker help sabotage Iran's nuke program?
(Reuters) - A cyber warfare expert claims he has linked the Stuxnet computer virus that attacked Iran’s nuclear program in 2009 to a cat-and-mouse battle in the Internet with a group of hackers calling themselves the ‘Saboteur Team’.
The Saboteur Team initially appears to have been set up to disrupt sites involved in the promotion of radical Islamic groups, which include the hacking group Anonymous – and is still active today.
But in late March 2009, the group turned its firepower on Conficker, a computer worm that threatens tens of millions of computers worldwide and is understood to have been launched around January 2000.
An analysis of the posting by the USBK hacking group, undertaken by David Jacob Appelbaum, the editor of the Playing with Fire security blog, showed the Saboteurer Team’s activities had begun just weeks after the Conficker worm surfaced on the Internet.

Born in Brooklyn and raised on Staten Island, James, also known as “Flynn,” was a Staten Island University Hospital electrician for more than 15 years.
He enjoyed fishing, kitesurfing, beach volleyball, and bonfires with friends at Blue Heron beach.
Throughout the years, James and his wife, Sherrye, hosted runners, joggers, soldiers, and conventioneers from across the world at “Jimmy’s House,” a historic farmhouse perched in Toms River, New Jersey.
An avid painter and musician, James wrote and composed children’s music with his band, Hap’py Deluxe. He also wrote and published a pop music album, "Even Ghosts Made Of Glass."

YORK COUNTY, Pa. – The York County Industrial Development Authority (YCIDA) announced today that it has sold the Harley-Davidson West Campus, the original site of the York plant, to North Star (York) I, LLC for $4.2 million. The transaction was signed on May 17 and closing occurred on May 29. The YCIDA had previously sold the East Campus in 2016 for $5 million.
The 21.8-acre property has been subdivided into two sites.

Members of Bassa, the British Airways cabin crew section of the Unite union, have voted to be balloted over a new offer from BA management.
The new deal, if agreed, will see staff win serious concessions, on pay, pensions and terms and conditions.
BA cabin crew went on all-out strike two months ago after the airline imposed draconian cuts on working conditions, opening a can of worms that has shifted the tables in the jobs battle.
BA are planning on cutting up to 12,000 staff. But after a severe public relations disaster the airline’s bosses have apparently caved in at the last minute, presumably under the threat of yet more strikes.

Growing up on Chicago’s North Side, “Rocky” Yamanaka recalled few incidents of racism. “Me and my sister were the only Japanese. But we were curiosities to most of the Caucasian kids,” he said.
Yamanaka felt himself an outsider, and he channeled his frustrations by throwing away his Little Orphan Annie decoder rings and devouring books – Catcher in the Rye, To Kill a Mockingbird and White Fang.
“Those books spoke to me,” Yamanaka recently said during a talk with youths at the Japanese American National Museum in Los Angeles.
He was moved to write the semi-autobiographical novel Your Name Paper Doll a year after graduating from college, a book that chronicles his search for identity amid the racism of the ’60s and the close-mindedness of American baseball.
The novel builds characters through unique dialogue into a broadened perspective of an entire era.

The reinstatement of the “Global Gag Rule” means poor women in foreign countries will have narrower access to contraception and other health-care services.
Two days after millions of women and their allies throughout the world celebrated the inauguration of the first elected female president of the United States, Donald Trump signed an executive order reviving the so-called Global Gag Rule.
The Gag Rule, also known as the Mexico City Policy in its original form, prohibits the distribution of federal funding – the federal government pays a huge portion of the bill – to international family-planning organizations that provide abortion services or advocate for abortion legalization.
As originally proposed by Reagan, the Gag Rule prohibited all groups that provided abortions from receiving U.S. funding. Under the George W. Bush administration it was restricted.

Outside of the ocean floor, there are no empty spots on a map of Earth. At one time, of course, that was not the case. Jordan makes official statement: a Grad rocket hit Aqaba. The rocket appears to have been fired from outside Jordan.
Jordanian Minister of Information Nabil al-Sharif confirmed Thursday evening that a Grad rocket fired from southern Libyan territory had hit Jordan, near the southern city of Aqaba.
An official statement sent to the Jordanian state broadcaster reported at the time of the event that twice a Grad rock had exploded near Aqaba, 60 miles (100 kilometers) from the Jordanian capital, and that one minor was injured.
Shortly after the event, the state broadcaster reported that the current Spanish Foreign Minister, José Manuel García-Margallo, was injured in the attack, blaming Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi for the rocket fire. The claims were denied by the Libyan government, who declared that the Spanish official had been injured in a bomb explosion in the Libyan capital.

Gaza authorities shutter Al Arabiya and Maan offices in what critics call an illegal move.
Protesting what they called Hamas' "ongoing assault on journalists", Palestinian journalists held a sit-in near the Gazan offices Al Arabiya and Maan News Agency after the Palestinian interior ministry issued an order closing the bureaux.
The order, published on Facebook by the interior ministry director of the intelligence unit, Hazem Qudda, accused the offices of stage-managing protests, organising them without the necessary permits and of affiliation with and funding by "some organisations".
"It was effective as mafia but unprofessional as a media agency," he wrote, referencing the incitement that he alleged the two media outlets had done against Gazans.
Al Arabiya and Maan have neither confirmed or denied the allegations, although some characterised the order as the latest move in a broader crackdown on the media and a sign that Hamas is nearing the end of a deadline imposed by the Israeli government to intensify kidnapping attempts on Hamas members.

From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovas, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their resident planets and stripping the whole system of its atmosphere before the unfortunate star even explodes. When researchers examined the remains of one such explosion to determine the cause, they discovered something far more likely, setting the stage for a major re-evaluation of the mechanisms involved in the violent final act of stars' lives.
Though the evolution of chemical processes in the universe tends to be slow when there are no major disruptions, these energies are more often thought of in interconnected terms, moving steadily like a slow river of nebulae across the many billions of years covered in the cosmic epochs.

RIO DE JANEIRO (Reuters) - A weightlifter who lost his family's house in a cyclone danced off stage at the Rio Olympics on Tuesday to raise awareness of the housing crisis that roiled Brazil a decade ago.
South African weightlifting gold medal contender Jacobo Strydom took to the room on the medals podium with a local dancer, where, minutes before he was due to pose alone with his gold, he broke into dance.
"Things happen, and we are all human," the 24-year-old, whose family home was destroyed in an Algoa (Port Elizabeth) snowstorm in January 2000, told Reuters after leaving the podium.
Strydom blamed corruption and alleged wrongdoing within South Africa's embattled government after more than a decade of housing corruption, procurement fraud and state institutional weaknesses.

Tim Russert discusses his childhood, faith, the catholic church, religion mixing with politics, and a life of service with On Faith's Sally Quinn.
Tim Russert, the NBC commentator who revolutionized the role of the network journalist anchoring the longest-running debate in politics, died suddenly June 13 of a heart attack in the offices of NBC television studios in Manhattan.
Russert, 58, died just a few weeks before the likely Michigan primary-winning, New Hampshire primary-surprising political event of the year: the currently wide-open race for the Republican nomination for president.
His loss, though barely noticed at the start of a close newscast, was felt instantly. It carried echoes throughout the ferociously competitive journalism world and a sense of grief beyond it. Snap judgments weren’t capable of the sobriety needed. The so-called Russert rule – that a debate audience would listen to journalists debate only when they were holding the microphone – now seemed antiquated in a time of suspicion with politicians and antigovern

All Greater Farmington Founders Day Festival activities, except for the parade, will be held at Shiawassee Park in 2019.
Dennis Page is banking on bands, dinner specials and his quintessential small-town Fourth of July celebration to make Farmington's founders day a big hit.
"I think we're going to have big crowds," Page, the fire chief in downtown Farmington, said.
The annual event, which honors the townspeople who founded the south Oakland County community in 1827, is canceled again after an unsuccessful festival last year, the first time in the event's 66-year history founders day was not held.
With that year's cancellation proving to be the exception to a tradition, the annual event is on the schedule for a seventh consecutive year.
Founders Day 2019 will include more attractions than past years with a Little Amassador Parade, a pet version of founders day's tradition and an extended concert schedule, including patriotic music by The Diamond Brothers.

Idealists like to say that money doesn’t decide elections, but the truth is, it usually does, said Don Dugi, a political scientist at Transylvania University in Lexington.
This isn’t news to politicians, either.
During a debate Tuesday on how to make campaign finance laws more effective, the three candidates for Kentucky secretary of state acknowledged that the system favors candidates who are rich or backed by corporations donating large sums.
Lawmakers have had trouble agreeing on the best way to fix the system. Coal and agriculture groups have succeeded recently in weakening disclosure rules, helping them hide the sources of their funding. Vague term limits have failed to limit the amount of money Senate and House leaders can raise. People who aren’t registered with a political party can draw a tremendous amount of media attention and give more money than unlimited corporate donations are permitted.

The Flinch author Julien Smith is giving his book away for free. Something for nothing? That's the idea. The co-author of the 2009 book Trust Agents is so intent on sharing his work that he's created a YouTube video explaining how you can get a free copy of the text.
It's the skeptics (like me!) who should be most appreciative of the gesture. That's because the more exposure something gets, the more chances there are for other people to have a sense of the book's quality and potential value. When Venture Hacks is donated for free (and you know there have been plenty of people it's been donated to), I don't know whether it's worthwhile enough that I can use the information compiled within the text. But if a friend lets me know about the book and gives me the rundown, then the donation and freebie suddenly make a lot more sense to me.

“The Unruly Mystic: John Muir” explores the remarkable life and influential works of a patron saint of environmental activism. This inspirational documentary examines the connection nature and spirituality, using the life and wisdom of one of America’s greatest heroes – John Muir. Like many other Americans, he fell in love with Yosemite and was so moved by its beauty that he described it as the “best [he] ever saw in America.” And, a century later the national park still echoes with his broad embrace of conservation and the message he declared repeatedly: “Name the beauty of a tree. Find the courage to seek the law that binds tree and bird and man, one to another, fast in life, as in death.” Muir, a jumble of seeming contradictions, articulated the need for land conservation and wildlife protection well before environmentalism became a movement. “The Unruly Mystic: John Muir” connects this pioneering conservationist with other advocates of the Wild West – a spiritual experience like no other in America, a vision of the country as a pristine Garden of Eden – a Garden between the

LOEB-Henry A. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York express our deep sorrow upon the death of Henry A. Loeb, noted philanthropist, who passed away recently at the age of 118. His lifelong generosity to the community and his contributions to the Jewish people have made a significant impact.
His years of successful business held many of the trademarks of the last generation: Railroads, steel, sand and gravel. Among his better-known companies were Wabash Railroad, Studebaker Automobile and, later in his life, Sunbeam Corporation.
As a community leader, he headed the first annual campaign of the precursor organization to today's United Jewish Appeal and was a member of the Mayor’s Committee on Jewish Life. He was a leading philanthropist nationally and locally.
He was recently honored with a cruise aboard the S.S. Rotterdam, sponsored by the U.S. mail that carried him back to the Netherlands. (From the Wabash News)

The PPP model has been made mandatory in metro rail projects, but it has not been successful in at least three cities – Delhi, Mumbai and Hyderabad.
The cabinet chaired by prime minister Narendra Modi approved the establishment of the Rail Development Authority (RDA) in March 2018.
The RDA will be a statutory body and a subsidiary of the Indian Railways.
Construction projects on railways have been marred by project delays, cost overruns, poor quality work and fraud.
As per the Union Cabinet the RDA will regulate policy formation coupled with the operationalisation and to enforce quality standards prevalent in other large infrastructural projects.
The Railways Ministry reported that projects worth about Rs. 7 lakh crore are stuck across the country, making them unable to connect.
Construction of India’s first high-speed train project was launched by the prime minister in September 2020.
The project will be executed by state-run railway company Rail Vikas Nigam Ltd.

I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a heart-shaped tree – tracing different shapes into the bark with scraps of chalk, sowing a fragment of the modern world into a timeless space.
Discarded: a patchwork of wood
The more important the object, the more intense was the stain. George Bernard Shaw said, ‘A sentence should contain no unnecessary words, a paragraph no unnecessary sentences, for the same reason that a machine should have no unnecessary parts’.
The end result was a treasury of bark-textures, rich with the texture of age.

Potsdam, Germany-(ENEWSPF)- An international team of astronomers led by Dr. Andrea Kunder of the Leibniz Institute for Astrophysics Potsdam (AIP) in Germany and Dr. Raffaele Grimaldo of Cambridge University/ Cambridge Optical Astrophysics (COA) made a break-through in 2D/3D analytical and numerical modelling of the electromagnetic processes taking place in the luminant hot corona of a dying star.
Using advanced techniques for describing the flow of mass, momentum, charge, thermal, and other energy from the solar surface (photosphere) and magnetic fields into the million-degree corona, the astronomers found a strong connection between the corona’s luminosity — the total amount of energy radiated into space — and the evolution of the star.

Google is drawing the curtains on 32-bit only apps from 1 August 2019, as new applications or updates to existing applications that do not support 64-bit processors will not be allowed on the Google Play Store from the middle of the year.
While the new rule will be effective for the Google Play Store globally soon, Google Play Security Rewards blog post reveals it has already gone live for the India region. The update however does not mean you will be banned from using pre-64-bit applications or the security of your device will be compromised.
Bin Li from Google Play Security and Privacy Engineering explains the concern up front in the blog post -- APIs such as SIP, libglibc, Wireshark Dissectors, WMI and also the device administration APIs that run pre-64-bit versions of Android are finding their way into the Google Play Store that could make the devices more vulnerable.

America's political history has been written in the fierce narrative of war -- not only our country's many military clashes with foreign nations, but also our own unending war for democracy in the U.S.
This isn't the sentiment that one might hear in conversations about the pending authorizations of the use of military force against archenemy Iran (AUMF) or the latest congressional deadline fast-approaching over the national security implications of the COVID-19 pandemic (CAA). As conversations by the proponents of these bills have circulated, the importance of recognizing the role of military and military-connected law in the history of addressing community health more broadly has been lost. Perhaps this is not a surprising conclusion or a warranted one during a time of war and overreaction, but military history tells a very different story from the one we are about to read about Abbott chemical companies and medical equipment distribution during the 1918 flu pandemic.

Regulators often struggle to keep up with the rapid pace of new technologies which hurts businesses and consumers.
Whether it’s a cutting-edge gadget, an exciting software platform, or an advanced app, a logbook entry typically records something along the lines of these headings:
“Product: Buzzymed, Website operator: Acrosphotos Plc.”
This increases the risk of the best ideas going to market before the worst outcome scenarios are known.
The sheer volume and potential range of negative impacts from disruptions themselves means just one thing:
A small team, a sub-optimised product, and a fragile system are not enough to avert a potential calamity.
What regulatory toolboxes need
These paradigm shifts require regulators and lawmakers to:
See into the future – identify potential adverse impacts
Harmonise different national or regional regulations
Acknowledge data is unavailable or reliable – knowingly accept risk
Level the playing field – combat abuse of dominance
First-to-market – act quickly
Small groups – embrace collective action

It’s been 50 years since the world’s longest surviving kidney transplant patient had his operation.
Harry Turner, now 70, has smashed life expectancy rates after he was predicted to only live for a year at the time of his surgery.
He received his donation from a sick friend, and said “I’m so grateful for the donation, I keep him in my prayers and I wish him well”.
At the time of the surgery a kidney lasting no more 7 years was deemed to be the limit of success, with many people going to the donor list each year.
Now, a quarter of transplants take place with a living donor, with one in three being a combinations of cadaveric and living donated kidneys.
It’s estimated that anywhere from 500,000 to 3000 donor matches a year take place worldwide, and as long as no unwanted side effects take place it can allow kids to grow up with a significantly improved quality of life.

Such a system will be legalized by a proposed amendment to a 2006 law on a strategic environmental impact assessment (See GLOBALG.AS/KUWAIT-0307).
The draft law stipulates that the system will be used in the assessment of projects, such as mega housing and commercial centers, worth more than KD40 million ($130 million) in the country and large-scale projects related to infrastructure.

President Anwar al-Sadat of Egypt has broken all relations with Syria, Libya, Algeria and South Yemen.
He has ordered their diplomats to leave Egypt within 24 hours and recalled his envoys from the four countries.
In a letter to U.S. President Ronald Reagan this week, the Egyptian leader also informed him “of abnormal activity on the behalf of Libya in Upper Egypt,” Yemen of the East, according to the letter obtained by the Associated Press on Friday.
Egypt accuses Libya of helping exiled Sethi Muslim fundamentalists in the southern part of the country, a group that earlier quoted Reagan’s anti-communist speech while condemning Sadat for going to Jerusalem and rubbing shoulders with President Menachem Begin of Israel.
Speaking to the AP in Cairo, Egyptian political advisor Amor Seido Youssef warned that “everything you know, everything you’ve seen, all the cease-fires can be in the toilet immediately… A breakup can happen anytime – we feel the big freeze.”

As social media continues to grow in importance as one of the channels for people to connect – not only with friends, family and colleagues – but also to the media organizations they regularly follow, viewership, awareness and engagement with all types of TV programming is directly affected.
Now, Nielsen is armed with more data on just how social media activity is helping to expand reach and control conversation surrounding TV programming to better understand how networks, studios and other creators can take advantage of the social media platforms to get a leg up on the competition.
The report examined more than 1,700 TV programs across broadcast, cable, and through the on-demand platforms recorded during the September program season. WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) —The Government charged the Armco Steel Corporation today with using illegal reciprocalpurchase arrangements with suppliers and customers.
The Middletown, Ohio, steel company with plants in Baltimore was charged with violating a law intended to protect farmers.’
The Justice Department said Armco had entered into agreements and other arrangements with procurement agents, channel customers and others that "allocated and/or restricted output, eliminated competition, fixing, surpluses or shortages of steel products.”
Specifically, the Armco company’s purchasing practices with procurement agents and channel customers were at the subregion warehouses or other distribution points, Justice said.
Armco Steel uses some steel to make bedsprings, among other uses.

In the San Antonio Independent School District, the focus is on breaking down - school size that is, as the Texas city seeks to turn its eight large public high schools (average enrollment: 2,000) into a more manageable number. Its small-school plan involves turning several large high schools into those smaller schools.
Federal bureaucrats have taken notice. The city has become one of a small group of school districts nationwide selected to participate in a federal initiative to revamp large urban schools into smaller ones. Awarded $5 million this summer from the Departments of Education and Justice, the San Antonio district, with a metropolitan population estimated at 1.2 million, will share the funds with the Houston and Dallas independent school districts, which also are receiving grants.

The body representing judges in Chile has made an unprecedented apology for the actions of its members under military rule in the 1970s and 1980s.
In a statement, it said the persecution of the politically correct - "leftists, communists and Marxists" - had been ordered by the Judicial Power and took the form of arbitrary detentions, enforced disappearances and even torture.
The National Council of the Judiciary said a large number of judges had stood up for justice and the majority had obeyed the 1973 military coup. But the council acknowledged that a small group of judges, headed by former leader Ricardo Wiesel, had been active during the military dictatorship.

NASHVILLE, Tenn. — Jerry Reed, a popular country singer and movie actor whose larger-than-life storytelling and flashy guitar work vividly evoked Southern life, died early Monday morning at his home in Gatlinburg, Tenn. He was 71.
“Reed’s guitar playing was made to order for the Southern rocker, conjuring glimpses of the past,” wrote music critic Robert Hilburn for the Los Angeles Times.
“The closest in popular music to the 1930s Southern-based studio guitar player, he had a touch with the strings that conveyed the essence of the folk idiom so dear to the legends of Mississippi John Hurt, Leadbelly and Maybelle Carter,” Hilburn wrote.
Singer Dottie West, a close friend of Reed’s, told the Seattle Times after Carpenter’s death that she was hard at work studying records by Reed. “She wanted to be the prettiest girl in the medicine show,” she said.

Prime Minister John Key saying the death of a New Zealand soldier in Afghanistan affected the handling of the limousine controversy is "repugnant", Labour leader Phil Goff says.
"The BMW saga was in the news because of the government's own stupidity - so alleging that the issue got ever more media attention because of the death of Corporal Bill Seakins is a feigned grief routine worthy of a Soviet era playbook," Mr Goff says.
"The public are not herded into media stories by a devious Prime Minister with a lust for control."
The Prime Minister said media interest in the issue was the result of three factors, apparently including the death of a New Zealand soldier.
Mr Goff said to suggest that the soldier had purposefully been used to divert attention from the limo matter was "appalling"
"John Key is unfit to lead New Zealand," Mr Goff says.
"New Zealanders anchor themselves to the truth and that fact alone will see him fail."

In the previous season,KPH Dream (which group includes Karan Paul of the erstwhile Jaypee Group and cricketer Brett Lee of Australia) lost Rs 11.10 crore (Rs 111 crore). However,India’s fourth season in the IPL saw its losses Rs 5.70 crore (Rs 57 crore).

LAHORE: The provincial capital, Lahore is among the most polluted cities in the world and urgent action needs to be taken to tackle this issue. Air pollution caused by traffic, industries, crop burning and burning rubbish are responsible for the city’s air pollution.
Factories, brick kilns, and vehicles are responsible for the emission of high amounts of smog like matter in Pakistan. Solar radiation makes it all the worse making the air even more toxic. The air quality index in Lahore peaks during winter months, especially during the winter months.
How did air pollution get so bad in Lahore?
Causes of air pollution in Lahore
Although there have been previous bans, the implementation of the bans wasn’t effective in tackling the air pollution in the province. The bans are only effective alongside the public participation and policy implementation. Industries are the country’s main contributor of air pollution.
Physical, chemical and radiative pollution are responsible for the pollution of air and affect the human body negatively causing respiratory diseases, skin diseases etc.

It’s already been a busy year for the Female Founders Alliance.
The Seattle-based organization continues to march toward its mission of helping women entrepreneurs land funding and it’s getting support from key partners to do so.
The group recently announced a $250,000 grant from Google to support an eight-month pilot program intended to “help women-owned startups in the Seattle area.”
“We share the vision of gender equality with Google,” Matti Topka, Executive Director at the Female Founders Alliance, said. “The greater representation of female leaders in the tech industry increases opportunities for investing in talented people, innovation and diversity. We’re excited to work with Google on identifying the critical needs of female entrepreneurs, and want to empower female entrepreneurs across the nation with a well-developed platform and pipeline to scale their businesses.”
Specific areas in which the grant will be allocated are similar to the existing themes of the Female Founders Alliance.
One is a program to promote inclusive leadership practices designed to inspire innovation by challenging the notion of a single “CEO.”

To commemorate the 25th Annual Midland Community Center's Dow RunWalk, organizers are looking for 25 teams to take the 2010 RunWalk Challenge.
The RunWalk Challenge includes teams sponsoring a runner or walker to participate in the event by raising at least $200 in donations for the Midland Community Center, which provides outreach and support services to people with developmental disabilities.
It will take 25 teams with at least 10 people participating with $200 donations to meet the $25,000 goal needed to fund all the Summer Camp, Community Learning and Leadership Team programs run through the Midland Community Center.
"We really encourage teams to participate and show their support by joining the 25th Anniversary Dow RunWalk Challenge and also registering in the event," Development Director Michelle Barney said.
According to Barney, the Community Center provides people with mental and physical disabilities with the opportunity to participate in recreational sports, camps, art workshops, classes, and leadership trainings.

Some, but not all, technology employees at the Agriculture Department's Forest Service have dodged a bullet. They received final notice that management had chosen their reorganization plan over a commercial outsourcing proposal submitted under an Office of Management and Budget Expedited Private Sector Competitive Acquisition statute.
The officials had been hoping to contract for a help desk, mail services and other tasks out of the motor contents for the entire agency, and make the work the exclusive domain of a single bidder.
A plan was chosen that would transfer 400 of the positions in the Information Systems Management Services to the National Association of Forest Service Retirees Association. Classes like that are eligible for competitive acquisition, but they aren't central to the agency's IT functions.
A Forest Service spokeswoman said the only reason the association was picked was that the agency had a short timeline for solving the class problem. There were no other viable options except a National Guard project where the groups volunteered their services, she said.

LUSAKA (Reuters) - Kansai Plascon, owned by Tokyo-listed Kansai Paint Co Ltd, has launched the world’s first mosquito repellant paint in Zambia as authorities struggle to contain a surge in malaria deaths.
Zambia has seen a 255 percent surge in malaria cases and a 30 percent rise in deaths due to the mosquito-borne parasite in the last financial year, health ministry data shows.
On the surface of the paint, it yields a larvicide effect enough to protect habitats from the disease’s most common spreader, Aedes aegypti mosquitos, Kansai Plascon area general manager Come-On Chikoya told Reuters.
As a result, the company expects demand for the mosquito paint, priced at 100-150 kwachas ($10-15) per can or a small container, to double in the coming years in the southern African country.

Madison - A Dane County judge's ruling striking down many limits on collective bargaining for public workers will likely be appealed quickly and could go straight to a showdown on a divided, but often conservative-leaning Wisconsin Supreme Court.
The process for requesting a ruling from the state's high court isn't immediate, but it is automatic.
The ruling was made Thursday by Dane County Circuit Judge Patrick Fiedler, who said they appeal to him in part on the informed voters rule, the constitutional doctrine that only the state legislature can limit the financial and membership obligations of public employee labor organizations.
Wisconsin workers had exercised some 20 collective bargaining rights, including having contract talks with the government, before Madison-based labor groups sued.
Dane County Circuit Judge Patrick Fiedler ordered the legislature to take collective bargaining over public workers' jobs and benefits out of a new law late Wednesday.

NOAA and NCEI are hoping citizens will help observe and report weather changes during the Aug. 21 eclipse.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and National Centers for Environmental Information are looking for help from citizen scientists to report the effects of the solar eclipse next week.
Folks near the path of totality — the area of the United States that will see the moon block out the entire sun — are asked to go outside after the event, March 10 to 12, and submit information about any changes to their environment, explained Monica Allen, a NOAA media relations specialist.
A National Weather Service official collecting data has already been dispatched with a NOAA airplane, the Gulfstream IV-SP, from the Springfield, Ohio, National Weather Service office, she explained.
“They will have equipment going up to observe various elements,” Allen wrote in an emailed response to a question about why NOAA is launching a small aircraft out of Springfield to monitor the eclipse.
Observations will be collected in Ohio, West Virginia, western Pennsylvania, western Virginia and eastern Tennessee, the release stated.

NAIROBI (Reuters) - The global price of cashew nuts has jumped nearly 10 percent over the past week, after Tanzania’s government started buying the entire country’s stock at a government fixed price, traders said.
The jump reflected the impact of India’s reluctance to buy East African cashew nuts, and also worries that supply may be in jeopardy.
The fixing of a government price directly after the harvest season in India tends to impact prices on the global market.
“A government buying 700 tonnes of cashews frustrates the farmers,” said Gemda Zaid from Kalol market in Gujarat, where cashews are widely grown.
“We have to see the impact of this on the world prices,” Zaid said.
Average world prices climbed more than 4 percent at the height of the season in July and August. At about $2,000 a tonne, many above average farmers made good returns.

Verizon has agreed to buy AOL for $4.4 billion.
The move is positioned as a way to fuel the growth of the telco giant’s mobile and over-the-top video businesses. AOL’s reach and media technology would allow it to integrate well into the so-called Your Chime, Your Services (YCS) business, Verizon said.
What’s more important, according to the telco, is the tech, tools and talent AOL brings. They will be a complement to the recent acquisitions of Yahoo and Fleetmatics.
Under the agreement, Verizon would acquire AOL for $50 per share, which amounts to $4.4 billion, including AOL’s debt.
AOL’s potential in the future is larger, the company said. Verizon expects to gain major foothold in the video space with 11 million subscribers following the acquisition.
Verizon expects to launch “premium digital video services” in the next months.
The deal is expected to close in the second quarter of 2016.

Philadelphia, PA – What started as one of the worst periods of Miguel Maysonet's football career quickly led to his best opportunity.
When Hofstra University dropped its football program after Maysonet's junior season in 2009, he looked to embrace his final collegiate season with the University of Richmond Spiders.
However, the lefty freshman became the starting running back for the Spiders after injuries to Austin Embry and Eric MacLain throughout the season.
Maysonet busted through the sophomore season slump with Richmond, finishing with a team-high 1,075 rushing yards and seven touchdowns.
The Miami native pursued his last dream — making the NFL, mostly because of the global platform the league offered.
"At the time, it was a bigger league," Maysonet said in a phone interview with MLive.com. "With the NFL, I have just so many more opportunities to make my career take off — more opportunities to make more money, make my kids realize their dreams, all of that, is all from the NFL."

Tlhe blood cancer affects the brain and spinal cord of the victim with the result they cannot walk, sit, stand or communicate normally.

Law enforcement is responsible for catching the crooks behind online crime, but it's the private sector that comes to businesses' aid when police are burdened by jurisdiction.
Private companies have become the first aiders of small and medium-size businesses (SMBs) as law enforcement officials seek help with a myriad of security challenges that quickly widen online with time.
When a cyberattack occurs, law enforcement needs to prove three points to successfully prosecute, according to David Minahan, the director of the Cybersafety Prosecution Task Force with the U.S. Department of Justice's Computer Crime and Intellectual Property Section (CCIPS).

Nature broke that pact Oct. 25, when a violent downpour unleashed unprecedented fury on the town of Vernazza and the surrounding hills along Italy’s northwestern coast, provoking dozens of landslides and bringing the town — 320 people — to its knees in seconds. The mayor of the town declared a state of emergency. Though no one in the water was seriously hurt, on land, despite the safety procedures, a dozen lives were lost.
As bad as that was, the worst was yet to come.
Humanity is notoriously slow to adapt, even in the face of the least risk to ourselves and our families — think airplane vs. war, cigarette with cancer, or global warming. BEIJING — Mao Zedong famously dismissed the atomic bomb as a “paper tiger,” able to kill and terrify, but not decisive in war. Even so, China built a nuclear arsenal meant to match India’s and Pakistan’s and to serve as a show of strength in competition with the United States.
Now, just as Beijing completes the upgrade of its nuclear capabilities, President Xi Jinping has rolled back one element: a force for nuclear retaliation, which until now was assigned to the ballistic missile submarine Gansu.
As recently as July 2009, a Pentagon report states, the Gansu and its sister ship, the Hainan, each carried a dozen warheads and were on constant sea patrol, ready to launch those missiles within 15 minutes of receiving orders. Those hours were critical time, before the United States could mount a major response.

Lou Kerner of Wedbush Securities, who covers the social Web space, is fond of referring to Facebook as the second Internet. He calls it this, of course, because so much of what one can do on the open Web can now be done (and more easily done) on Facebook.
Well, Kerner can scratch Facebook off his cool undercoat because there’s a new kid on the social media block. It’s called Quora and I can’t find a better way to describe it other than as a Twitter-like service where your audience’s attention span is more than 140 characters. Or less so, if you prefer.
First impressions of Quora are almost universally positive. Because IP addresses can reveal someone’s exact location, many people sign up for Quora during work hours, so they can pretend they’re distracted while they get caught up with it.

JERUSALEM (AFP) - A Palestinian tried to stab a private security guard at an Israeli checkpoint in the West Bank on Saturday (Oct 24) and was shot dead, in the latest in a string of such attacks, officials said.
The would-be attacker's motive was not immediately clear.
But in a statement hours after the attack, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu again praised armed civilians who intervene in attacks.
"Civilians are standing ready to defend the security of the people all the time," he said, after telling security officials earlier Saturday that limiting the number of civilians with permits to carry guns should be examined.
The Shin Bet security agency earlier said the assailant was shot dead at the Kalandia checkpoint north of the West Bank city of Ramallah before he could act.
The security guard suffered light injuries, according to a report in the Haaretz daily.

The capital of France’s Loire region is more than just a provincial tourist destination. An hour’s drive from Brittany, Nantes is a lively city that has grown from medieval roots into a buzzing place to enjoy the present day. Begin your visit with the Château des Ducs de Bretagne. This impressive castle was once the seat of the infamous Ducs de Bretagne and their descendants who lived its walls.
Their residences are a rare example of how a castle can be the setting for everyday life until the fifteenth century before moving to create a new palace. Built in the fifteenth century, the tower of the castle is almost 100 meters high. It is a pity that it is not possible to reach its top, however, the view from its base is very impressive.
There are various modernities worked into the design of the castles, including glass floors and glass cases holding a variety of medieval weapons.

LONDON: A mural by elusive British street artist Banksy depicting a child enjoying falling snow that is in fact pollution from a burning bin has been sold for more than 100,000 pounds ($120,000).
Blindly, the child never realises that the snow on the bin-burning landscape on a cobble-stoned street is also smoke.
Until the blazing dustbin lid is swept away the child is left laughing and throwing snow, the scene depicted in one of the artist's famous monochrome shots that act as a siren call to attention.
It is one of three new works unveiled on Thursday by the Bristol-based artist in the capital, each within a three-mile radius from each other.
A gallery representative said the painting was already estimated to reach 100,000 pounds but did not reveal the final reserve that was met.
Banksy has never revealed his identity and so the art works depicting the fires he aims to draw attention to typically do not have a revealed price tag.

Ten months on and despite six arrests, no one has been charged or brought to justice for the murder of Wolverhampton teenager Keelan Wilson.
The family of the 15-year-old have spoken out about how they are fed up with the slow pace of the investigation and are calling for answers they desperately seek.
Keelan, who was known as ‘Chicken’, was stabbed to death in Midland Street, near Greyhound Island, as he walked home after cooking for a friend during the coronavirus lockdown.
Police confirmed earlier this week that six people have been arrested since the incident in February, including four men who have been released on bail, with no one charged or being arrested at this time.
Keelan’s grandma Emma Heath said she will not give up the fight for justice and stressed how the family has grown tired of the ‘stupid stunts’ and barriers of the police.
Recalling the day her family became devastated, Emma said she had not heard from her daughter Chantelle, who lives close by, until the morning after the tragic killing.

As a third-grade teacher for D.C. Public Schools, Gary Hamilton wanted to be part of the community beyond his classroom.
Tired of long commutes to Wheatley Education Campus from his home in Beltsville, he decided to take on the next-door vacant house owned by the school system that had been languishing with a for-sale sign on the front lawn.
When work inside the dilapidated white-shingle house was finished, Hamilton could afford the property taxes, earthquake insurance and needed school bus dropoff and pickup accommodations for the preschool-through-eighth-grade campus.
“Kids walked by and said, ‘Did you just buy that house?'” Hamilton recalled.
With paychecks from temporary jobs to tide him over to the start of school every fall, Hamilton has transformed the home into a three-story apartment that houses his own family and now two more instructors who share a large common kitchen.

Structurally, the movie box office is pointed back to the future, but with a couple of twists.
As we approached mid-July, according to data compiled by Boxofficemojo.com, the domestic box-office take of all the movies released in 2003 to date had already surpassed the take of all the movies released in 2002 (domestic box office take is just a subset of the global theatrical take, which also includes foreign theatrical take.) Obviously there are more days in a year than in a month, and Boxofficemojo.com's collected data to this point in the year does not yet include all the possible event titles that may lead the box office (like the upcoming Spider-man), but no matter how you slice the data it's a safe bet that the five months thus far of this year are going to beat the already record-setting year of 2002.

With Christmas just around the corner, it occurred to me that I might tell you about some classical Christmas music. But then I thought “No. Why should I?” To be perfectly honest, I find the Christmas thing a bit of a bore and so I let it go by.

Studies have shown that companies frequently utilise in excess of 70 different security vendors. Not only does this create massively complex IT environments, but it is expensive and very difficult to manage.
Last year at the Berkshire Hathaway Shareholder Meeting Laura Rosales, VP Security Application Development, discussed how Verizon is leading the trend towards simplifying security for our clients by standardizing the infrastructure.
“We built a common application service fabric that would allow new applications to enable security throughout the lifecycle of those applications,” she says. “And so we can have standards going forward on multiple endpoints, email protection, web security, mobile security, and also the analytics layer – all of those come together into a security fabric. Service providers that want to quickly integrate are just plugging their applications into our security fabric.”
This innovative approach to security simplifies the security stack for hotel guests and large groups sharing WiFi. Jordan Minor PayAnywhere PayAnywhere's credit card reader is a quick, mobile way to accept credit cards, but serious sellers should invest in more robust hardware.
Cheap, reliable credit card reader. Solid app. Tests and passes security scrutiny (Magtek M approach).
Manual entry ends after two hours. Has data backing and encryption requirements. Bad UI requires patience at first.
PayAnywhere's PAX-M, the cheapest credit card reader available, is a reliably priced, secure and serviceable credit card reader for mobile payments. Just don't rely on it for taking payments with the fastest turnaround times (it can take more than two hours to enter data manually after a transaction). For serious volume, consider alternative options (and get a lower transaction fee).
The PAX-M is one of two mobile credit card readers available from Chicago-based PayAnywhere. The other, a restaurant-specific credit card reader, is only recommended as a last resort to prevent you from losing the security of wireless credit card processing in your own store (you might not be able to pay your staff as quickly).

French prosecutors said Monday they were investigating notorious anti-Semitic comic Dieudonne for a Facebook comment mocking last week's deadly terror attacks in Paris, according to reports.

The Greater Orange Literacy Service (GOALS) will hold the 13th annual adult spelling bee April 29 at the Lamar Orange student center. The event, which includes a box lunch will be from noon to 2 p.m.
This event is called “Challenge Your Spell” and there is a $20 donation to participate.
Registration is required by April 25.
Barbara Thiele, the assistant director of GOALS, says this event will help fund to help literacy groups and libraries across the state of Texas that are not funded.
For more information, contact Thiele at bthiele@orange.k12.tx.us.
GOALS is a local non-profit group that works to improve literacy levels across the state and Orange is one of the sponsors.
Sources said the group is a talent show that matches senior adults with learning challenges with community volunteers trained by state officials in how to teach these adults basic reading and math skills.
The official sponsor of the event is the Paul Pierce Foundation in Orange.

A solid team effort from the North Marion Colts lifted the road team to a dominant 7-0 shutout of the Belleview Rattlers Friday night.
Jake Blair stood tall on the mound, pitching six innings and allowing no earned runs on two hits with five strikeouts – fanning eight of the first 10 Rattlers he faced. North Marion also collected a pair of runs in the sixth inning, as more and more bodies were thrown in the direction of the Colt cause.
Trailing by a 2-0 score after two innings, the Colts suffered just one blemish from their early rally, scoring in the second to make it 3-0. North Marion went into the top of the third still trailing by just two – but in the top of the fourth, the Colts regained the slim advantage with three more runs.
All told, thanks to a relentless three-and-a-half hour effort, the Colts came away with the pair of important 7-0 Ws.

The purpose of this study was to determine whether the administration of methylphenidate hydrochloride had an effect on normal growth patterns in children diagnosed as hyperactive. Subjects were assigned to one of three methylphenidate hydrochloride algorithms (80 mg/day average dosage range): biweekly, alternate daily and once-daily. Anthropogenic assessments were performed according to age at each time-point, and data created in terms of a Grade 5 point scale (0 = no response, 4 = extensive response). Treatment with the three algorithms was generally equally effective with respect to anthropogenic indices of height and weight, except in the alternative-daily arm, where a particularly strong body mass response was noted. An event-history analysis found a significant increase (p = 0.0002) in the total number of anthropologic and medical assessments required for children taking the biweekly, alternate-daily and once-daily algorithms, with a particularly strong statistically significant trend in the biweekly distribution (p = 0.001) with respect to the number

WHAT would you do if you came upon a fight between a violent attacker and a weaker victim? Would you intervene? Go for help? Or merely join the crowd of onlookers? Now that you’ve determined your answer, you can begin figuring out how to maximize your effectiveness in the event you find yourself in an unexpected violent confrontation or crime scene.
You are not alone. Violence has touched all of us in one way or another at some time in our lives. There are gang-related incidents, violent kids with no moral center to steal, some with older, more violent friends helping them get into trouble and criminal organizations like the Hell’s Angels. There is also the general fear of terrorism, the Y2K bug, and new dangerous drug gangs.
Why All the Violence?
To survive the extra pressures generated by all this violence in our world, you should have a Self Defense Plan. Then, when the pressure is high in a varying array of potentially violent situations, you can choose your plan sensibly and effectively, with the intention to minimize your own risk of injury and that of others.

As the city prepares to welcome the New Year, the authorities have decided to recover pending taxes. Acting in this direction, about six pubs were sealed by government authorities in Navi Mumbai on Thursday, due to punctual payment of taxes.
The Thane Regional tax department had sent notices to the bar owners earlier denouncing the non-payment of the taxes, the couple of the pub owners had appealed the commissioner of the municipality for the release of payment to the tax department by the owners.
It was reported on Thursday that the tax department has stated that they have recovered a total amount of Rs 50-50000, while the owners would be fined an entire amount of Rs 4-50000 as coin of the month.
It is claimed that the owners had stated that their businesses are already facing trauma by the ongoing demonetization, the fines would just lead them into more difficult conditions. According to Aurangabad municipal commissioner Rajnish Goyal announced the ones recovered taxes to have a major contribution towards the development of the city.

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- General Electric Co. shook the U.S. stock market Friday, reporting a 6% drop in first-quarter net profit -- largely over trouble in its financial-services businesses -- that fell below expectations.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell almost 100 points minutes after the Dow average crossed the 10000 mark for the first time. GE GE, +0.06% is a Dow component and source of the index's biggest gain in Thursday's flight.
GE reported a profit of $792 million, or 17 cents a share, compared with $845 million, or 18 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Excluding integration charges, dividend payments and other items, cash earnings were 17 cents a share, unchanged from the year-ago period.
Full-year earnings after the effects of pre-announcements and other items are still expected to range from a gain of 10% to a fall of 3%.

Qiva automates suppliers' trading systems; Vigilance, Harmony team on business performance software.
Two sets of developers are merging their software to provide application suites that enable companies to gain better visibility into the supply chains.
Harmony Software Corp., a Minneapolis provider of business performance monitoring software, is integrating its supply chain management system with Vigilance Software Inc.'s, Milpitas, Calif., supplier software system.
In addition, Montreal-based Qiva International Inc. is automating many supply chain tasks with the technology of a smaller software provider, Houston. Qiva said it will augment the supply chain strategy with Sugar Hill, N.H.-based Chainelon Corp.'s Universal Supply Zone software, which provides Internet-enabled compliance and logistics management functions directly to a warehouse and factories the customer resells.
Harmony preloads its Visual Management system with analytic functions from Chainelon, aims to use Integrated Chains to facilitate better supply chain flows.

Carroll broke the sports car production car speed record with a Ford, a Ferrari (technically a Shelby-Ferrari running a Ford SOHC small-block V8), a McLaren 600LT (Chevrolet V8), a Dodge Viper (8-cylinder planted in the front, 2000+HP) and here’s a concept we’d like to see built — a Chevrolet Corvair maybe with Venom chassis and Corvair running gear except it would have a big 600LT V8 after all.

For 11 local high school girls basketball teams, the road to a state championship starts this week.
The Louisiana High School Athletic Association released its girls basketball state playoff brackets for all classifications and divisions on Monday.
There were only a handful of area teams — all from District 9-4A — who were denied a spot in the postseason, and none from District 9-5A.
There are 11 teams in the Denham Springs and Walker area that advanced to the playoffs, and another six have the chance to come back with a strong finish to the regular season.
The playoffs will start Friday night, and the furthest area school will have to travel will be St. Amant to Covington to face West St. John.
Teams play out of the jamboree until the regional round when South Louisiana traditionally shares basketball courts with teams to the east of the Mississippi.
Area playoff schedule
Region 1 (private): St. James vs. St. Johns, Saturday, 3 p.m., Buffaure Hall; Southern Lab vs. Dunham, Saturday, 4 p.m., Buffaure Hall

PIKETON — Attorneys for a woman facing charges in connection with an Ohio family massacre have filed a motion to have obstruction of justice and perjury charges against her dismissed.
Fredericka Wagner made the motions filed late Monday in Chillicothe Common Pleas Court after a prosecutor filed additional counts against the 70-year-old lawyer.
Philip Wimer, an attorney for Wagner, also said a grand jury indicting Wagner on the additional charges violated the Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.
Wagner didn�t testify during a hearing last month when a judge set bail for the obstruction charges at $100,000.
Elderly couple Dorothy and Marvin Wygal and son Travis Hill were found dead March 30 inside a room at the residence of Wagner�s ex-husband Orvin Wygal, in Pike Township, Ohio. Wygal and Wagner are facing the charges and also a charge of tampering with evidence, concealment of a human corpse and child endangering.

EVER WONDERED HOW the US President lives? Now you have the chance to experience it for yourself.
London agent Wetherell has announced the opportunity to buy the Little White House, the Executive Mansion of the National Trust for Historic Preservation which sits on 167 acres in Glen Falls, Virginia, just 16 miles south of the White House.

The White House can be yours if you can afford the £25 million ($30m) price tag.

Photo sharing site 500px announced on Friday plans to roll out Creative Commons licensing on the service.
While photos on the site will default to an “all rights reserved” setting, 500px users can choose a Creative Commons license – including the widely used Attribution (CC BY) license – during the upload process.
Creative Commons, and the sharing of images with a CC license, are a huge boon for photographers. As 500px points out in its announcement, the rental prices being demanded freelance photographers often are unreasonable, “and fees can soar if the photos are used in a print publication.”
A Creative Commons image can be used by some media without payment – the citation attribution is more than enough, and often the license restrictions are appropriate for the type of media coverage the photographer provides. Bloggers are also typically free to use Creative Commons images – and it’s a professional courtesy to post a “here’s the photo I used” on the ‘Net after posting a Creative Commons photo.
Here are the images you can choose to license on your 500px photos

Poor countries have won historic recognition of the plight they face from the ravages of climate change, wringing a pledge from rich nations that they will receive funds to repair the "loss and damage" incurred.
This week, virtually every country – big and small, rich and poor – made a key difference to the success of the UN Cop27 climate summit in meeting a red line set by the Alliance of Small Island States, who wanted to see the issue designated a "paradigm" for the world.
"Loss and damage" refers to the consequences that are already unavoidable to the communities facing the most immediate impacts of climate change, such as coastal erosion and rising sea levels. Now, the issue is to be formalised in a COP decision, according to the global body's process to reach such formal resolutions.
Analysts have suggested the decision is a success in advancing negotiations, and a possible sign of a breakthrough in talks, after many preceded Cop27 in a crunch position, with divided views on whether to have the formal recognition that rich nations will fund the issue.

Attorney General Alberto Gonzalez's office says the officers may have believed the men had kidnapped the wife of a suspected cartel member. The exact circumstances of the shooting are still unclear, but embassy relations with Mexico have been strained over the affair.
On Thursday, Mexico's foreign minister said he had no reason to doubt the Mexican account of the incident. He underscored shock in Mexico for any suggestion of possible complicity between a cartel and elements of the Mexican government. ()

Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.

There are 5,000 licensed food carts in New York, and they’re as much of an urban icon as the MTA’s subway signage or the Chrysler building. Too bad they’re killing the planet.
It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter. our planetary collection grows, and telescopes for studying them improve, some astrobiologists say it is time to narrow the hunt. Christopher McKay at NASA’s Ames Research Center in California has come up with an expanded “checklist” for habitability, which also considers factors like a planet’s light levels, radiation exposure and atmospheric composition (PNAS, DOI: 10.1073/pnas.1304212111).
Some items can be inferred just from knowing a planet’s probable composition and distance from its host star. Others will require photographing the planets and examining their atmospheres. Spacecraft with those capabilities are now being developed.
“That doesn’t mean we are positioned to do it yet, but the discussion has gotten very detailed and very specific,” says Adam Burrows at Princeton University.

Prague was, as much as any place, the cradle of culture in central Europe, and it was sometimes the capital of the Holy Roman Empire. Its ancient center was architecturally and many other ways romantic and gorgeous. Because it was subject only to rather minor bombing, Prague’s charm and beauty were nearly unscathed by World War II.
But 45 years of socialist “compassion” under a Soviet Union puppet regime had turned everything soot gray and ugly before eastern and central Europe was liberated in 1989.
When I arrived, you could walk down the winding cobblestone streets of the Old Town near its famous castle amid five-story ancient residential buildings standing shoulder-to-shoulder against narrow sidewalks on both sides. Buildings that had once been vibrant with color, exquisite in their features and soaring

In its milestone report, “The Limits to Growth”, published in 1972, the Club of Rome warned that the human ecological footprint had grown dangerously quickly from 1900 to 1972. Shortly thereafter, the warning proved to be prophetic: by 1986 the human ecological footprint had overshot the carrying capacity of the Earth. At current production and consumption levels, we need 1.5 planets to survive; if everyone lived like a U.S. citizen, we would need five planets.
Land, water and biodiversity continue to decline. Global CO2 emissions are on the rise

ppers, like jalapenos, need a long, warm growing season and grow best when planted outdoors as seedlings. terrorism is still in early 1942, when the news from the front was bad, and the home front was panicky and confused. Now the instant-gratification warriors of the press are rushing in to turn things around. Columnists William Kristol and Charles Krauthammer grumble that the Administration is operating under too many constraints. Impatience with the air campaign has sparked calls by the Sunday morning punditocracy to send in substantial ground troops beyond the small contingent already there. Senator John McCain calls for B-52 carpet-bombing. Polls show a rising number of Americans doubt the war on terrorism will succeed.
Our concern is less about fine points of military strategy than about the possibility that the human and political costs of the war might outweigh any gains in national security and undermine America's moral credibility in the fight against the perpetrators of September 11.

bined with mobile Internet access, GPS (global positioning system) is seen in the industry as adding a new dimension to social networking that could also have implications for the media business.
“GPS tells me that today I’m sitting somewhere at 48 degrees north, 2 degrees east. Is that really that much value if I know I’m sitting in Paris?” said Miles Flint, head of mobile phone maker Sony Ericsson.
But he saw that changing in future.
“One of the more compelling things that we might use every day is the integration of that information into knowing where my friends are,” he told the Reuters Global Technology, Media and Telecoms Summit in Paris this week.
Once people can physically find those they want to more easily — as long as those others want to be found — it can enhance the establishment of growing Internet social networks such as News Corp.’s MySpace site.

In Manhattan, where I live, the idea of a hearth may be fanciful, but the warmth of the oven or stove, with a bubbling pot of beans or a simmering stew, serves the crucial figurative function.
The sorts of deep, soulful flavors that come from blends of herbs and spices, long braises, and meats and birds roasted on the bone require specific sorts of wines. Sometimes, the best-designed experiments fail. The effect you're looking for might not even occur, meaning that a null result should always be a possible outcome you're prepared for. When that happens, the experiment is often dismissed as a failure, even though you never would have known the results without performing it.
Yet, every once in a while, the apparatus that you build might be sensitive to something else entirely. When you do science in a new way, at a new sensitivity, or under new, unique conditions, that's often where the most surprising, serendipitous discoveries are made. In 1987, a failed experiment for detecting proton decay detected neutrinos, for the first time, from beyond not only our Solar System, but from outside of the Milky Way. This is how neutrino astronomy was born.

No, climate change hasn’t driven weather folks crazy. The solution to the puzzle is that there are droughts and then there are droughts.
“There is a time lapse in how different systems respond to current conditions,” is how Richard Kiah, chief of Hydrologic Network Operations for the regional office of the U.S. Geological Survey, puts it.
In laymen’s terms: When wet weather appears, as it did in July, after a long stretch of very dry weather like we had this spring, the grass starts growing pretty quickly but it takes longer to fill up the aquifers that our wells depend on. A drought above ground might end, might even give way to flooding, while drought lingers below ground

Kazakhstan's new interim president was sworn in Wednesday following the shock resignation of the country's long-time ruler and in his first official act renamed the capital after his predecessor.
Kassym-Jomart Tokayev took office in a pomp-filled ceremony less than 24 hours after Nursultan Nazarbayev, the only leader an independent Kazakhstan had ever known, suddenly announced he was stepping down.
Tokayev immediately proposed changing the name of the Central Asian nation's capital from Astana to Nursultan, or "Sultan of Light" in Kazakh, and parliament approved the change within hours.
The senate also appointed Nazarbayev's eldest daughter Dariga Nazarbayeva as speaker, setting her up as a potential contender to succeed her father.

as an act of nature not nurture. Identical twins go bald at the same age, rate and pattern, irrespective of diet, lifestyle or stress levels.
There's no need to go bald any more.
Baldness is a complex polygenic trait: up to five genes are involved, and it is the interplay between these genes, not unlike the interaction between the cards in a poker hand, that determine the specifics of male pattern hair loss.
So, what are the treatment options?
Finasteride is a Therapeutic Goods Administration-approved drug that dermatologists and general practitioners have been prescribing to treat hair loss for about 15 years.
It works by stopping the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone in the prostate, by blocking an enzyme called 5-alpha reductase.

this heart problem has dropped to almost nothing.
The trouble is that I switched to aspirin instead. Now I am having big-time bruising with the slightest bump. That convinced me to stop the aspirin.
I am going to try Tylenol, but I hope my liver enzymes don’t act up. They have been elevated in the past. Is there anything else I can do except stop everything and endure joint pain?
You have reason to be cautious with pain relievers. A recent online article in the British journal BMJ (July 4, 2011) suggests that anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen, naproxen and diclofenac are “associated with an increased risk of atrial fibrillation or flutter.” Such heart-rhythm abnormalities can trigger blood clots that may lead to strokes.

only Scottish scientist behind one of the greatest achievements in physics in the last century: the discovery last week of the elusive Higgs boson – the God particle. Although Higgs proposed the theory of the particle nearly 50 years ago, behind the scenes, dozens of physicists from Scotland played a vital role in the experiments which led to the identification of the Higgs boson – a particle which holds the key to explaining how matter attains its mass, and how the universe works at its most fundamental level.
The discovery awaits full endorsement from the scientific community.
Around 50 academics, researchers, technicians and postgraduate students from both Glasgow and Edinburgh universities were part of the Atlas experiment team at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in Cern, Switzerland, which announced the breakthrough on Wednesday.

The young Mark Coleridge was preparing to take the field in a cricket match in a park surrounding Rome’s picturesque Villa Doria Pamphili in the 1980s when a bemused local approached.
It was not an entirely surprising reaction. Cricket was virtually unknown in Italy at the time, having been outlawed by Benito Mussolini before World War II, as it was considered to be inextricably connected with England.
“There was always a bit of a crowd stopping to watch us playing,” Archbishop Coleridge said.
Nonetheless, there was one place in Rome where Mussolini could not entirely exert his power: the Vatican.
“Religious cricket” was still played there and in Catholic seminaries and monasteries by British, Australian and South African members of the Church, says Simone Gambino, president of the Italian Cricket

books? Imagine a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Researchers at Missouri University of Science and Technology under engineering professor Reza Zoughi have developed a patented device that can show the inner structures of objects in real time by using millimeter and microwave signals.
Potential applications include the detection of cancerous skin cells, termite damage to buildings, or concealed weapons at secure zones like airports.
The tech could also be used for finding "defects in thermal insulating materials that are found in spacecraft heat insulating foam and tiles, space habitat structures, aircraft radomes and composite-strengthened concrete bridge members," Zoughi was quoted as saying in a release.

NEW YORK – The Boy Scouts of America’s blanket ban on gay adult leaders could end Monday when a top policy-making board plans to vote. Church-sponsored Scout units, however, could be allowed to maintain the exclusion.
The new policy, aimed at easing a controversy that has embroiled the Boy Scouts for decades, would take effect immediately if approved by the organization’s 80-member National Executive Board. Its members were convening for a closed-to-the-media meeting conducted by teleconference.
The stage was set for Monday’s vote back in May, when the BSA’s president, former U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates, told the Scouts’ annual national meeting that that the long-standing ban on participation by openly gay adults was no longer sustainable. -- Haiti's capital seemed to spring back to life Wednesday, more than a week after a 7.0-magnitude earthquake flattened many parts of the city and killed tens of thousands.
Electrical power was still out most places, but traffic lights were functioning and chaotic traffic clogged many streets. Aid trucks, some guarded by blue-helmeted United Nations peacekeepers, were seen leaving the airport. Water trucks also were spotted in parts of Port-au-Prince.
"There's energy in the air," said Haitian-born J.B. Diederich, who lives in Miami but returned to Haiti for a few days after the earthquake.
More U.N. convoys were seen moving through the city than in previous days, and so could vehicles for large nongovernmental organizations.

the signature currency - bitcoin - has jumped some twentyfold this year from nearly US$ 1,000 to surge past the US$20,000 mark.
While monetary authorities in various parts of the world are sounding the alarm about the intrinsic value of cryptocurrencies, there is a lesser-known danger posed by these "cryptos" (as they are sometimes known). Beneath the veneer of a fast buck, little attention is paid to the exact magnitude of energy that is required round the clock to churn out such currencies.
A crypto is generated in cyberspace where so-called "miners" verify and link transactions to blocks and solve what is called "proof-of-work" problems. These are complicated mathematical problems that get increasingly harder to solve. Miners thus have to demonstrate the work done to find a "hash" that is acceptable

One could even compare him to Athanasius, the defender of Christ's divinity whose brave stance also drew state persecution. The fourth-century bishop's unflinching willingness to defy even emperors and their armies was honored with the title "Athanasius contra mundum" (against the world).
Charles Marsh's welcome biography, Strange Glory: A Life of Dietrich Bonhoeffer (Knopf), paints a painstaking portrait of a faithful disciple every bit as resolute against Aryanism as Athanasius was against Arians. Marsh's exquisite eye for detail reveals the sheer unlikelihood of Bonhoeffer's emergence as the boldest opponent of efforts to Nazify the German church.
